090042.question: 'maybe i could eat blades of grass' seems to have this weirdly defeated tone in comparison to your other stuff. the intro sets up a questioning vibe, and the question turns out to be 'why is everything so dumb and stupid'; and after some excursions and attempts at looking at some things in the real world, all of which we've actually done, it seems like we come to actually admit that the hypothesis is true: everything is stupid. (which is interesting, because that's technically not the question that was asked; that's a reaffirmation of what the question presumed to be true already in its phrasing, that everything was stupid. but it also might be an answer to the question anyway, in the stupidest possible way: everything is stupid because it's stupid. that's a pretty stupid answer, which seems about right.) the 'rock in a plaid shirt' part seems to be a kind of last-ditch effort at something that isn't stupid, something new, but it all goes w rong, an d it sounds like (with the falling pitches and the final kick drum hit on 'stupid') that the end of blades of grass really was meant to be an admission of defeat. i just thought this was odd considering that you seem to be a fan of stupid; the two 'stupid songs' you've made seem to suggest you think stupidity can get you to stronger songs, videos, etc. but in blades of grass it seems like stupidity stands for a lack of meaning, and there's no way you're trying to say that nothing means anything - that's like the ultimate anti-bill wurtz sentiment as far as i can tell. let me know if any of this seems comprehensible to you. thanks
090042.answer: after discussing with my therapist, i think i can see exactly what is happening here. This is the 3rd one of these, and i think what is becoming painfully clear at the time of writing (or perhaps soon after) is perhaps it's time to try writing something with multiple characters

090181.question: there is such clear and smooth sub bass in hello sexy pants, how did you achieve this EQ wise without a muddy mix? is it a pure sine wave below the fuller bass sound or something? or do i just suck at designing bass sounds?
090181.answer: for that song, i mixed most of it in the car. i spent several entire days in the car, parked, working on the mix, in the car speakers. This is because i was tired of how volatile car speakers always are. Any tiny problem with the eq is usually a total disaster in the car. at least that's the way it seemed at the time. so i decided to take things into my own hands, and micromanage every moment of that song. almost every part of every instrument has its eq adjusted on a moment to moment basis. this might have been a terrible waste of time

090195.question: why was the time between the draft composition/writing of "and the day goes on" and its release date 699 days?
090195.answer: i will explain the timeline so hopefully it will make sense. in march 2015, the instrumental idea for the verse occured to me. i was not expecting it, it was not a planned 'writing session'. This is how many songs get started, they drop out of the sky, so you have to get good at catching them. So, this is me catching it. (march 2015). Sure, i could have immediately gone into a writing session for that idea, but, why not instead for an idea i had had the previous day? or a video idea i had had the previous day? it is always raining ideas. There is always more to be done than there is time to do. In march 2015 i had developed a 2 pronged approach: 2 short videos per week, and 'everything else'. I was doing 2 short videos per week just to have something to release, then in between, move forward on longer projects. I had a randomized selection scheme to help choose which longer projects to do. Near to that time, the 'crazy/raining' song was selected. That took several weeks. After that, it was the 'free to do whatever you want to' song. This took even longer. What also was happening at the same time was, my short videos had taken off on the vine platform. So i had made the decision to start vinifying my entire video catalog starting with the earliest, and posting them to vine every day. Around august (2015) i reached the end of the catalog so i had to make a decision about what to do going forward. i decided the vines were doing so well that it became important to make 7 new ones per week. This was unfortunate for my longer video aspirations, because it pretty much meant zero time leftover to pursue that. but it was important to keep things rolling on vine. So i carried on like this for about 2 more months, but my desire to make long videos was getting even more intense. I discovered a trick, where i could spend the first half of the day working on a long video, and not start the vine until the second half of the day, which forced me to do them much quicker. so i started on history of japan (oct 2015). i continued on like this, doing short videos while doing a long video, and finally around january i was getting into the scoring process (final stage) of the japan video and decided that i should pause the vines in order to finish the japan video more quickly. japan was finished by late january, it went to youtube and did very well there. i took this as a chance to put together a project i had always really really wanted to do but never found time: to make videos out of journal edits. i had about 6 years of audio journal content, and i combed through it as best i could, making video edits to attempt to chronicle my journey. After about 2 months working on this, i really had to cut it short because it was going on way too long. so i really only got to do about 10% of what i wanted. Also the other half of that project was for improv footage. I had to cut that way way short because no regular videos were being done during this time. So i only got a chance to do maybe 2% of the improv edits i wanted to do. So finally around May (2016) i was ready to get back to regular videos. there was so much i wanted to do, and didn't even know where to begin. I started extremely short, as i normally do, with a plan to make them gradually longer. I started making an agenda list of the sequence of upcoming items, and i wanted to include some medium length songs. Choosing from a list of hundreds, one of the ones i chose was that instrumental chord sequence back from march 2015. So i wrote that into a full song, over a couple of days. this song was called 'and the day goes on.' Among other short videos, there was also another song that i selected at that time, for release soon after. which i also wrote fully at that time. called 'hallelujah'. we are around june 2016 now. Then, suddenly, i felt a lot of public outrage that i was 'still doing short videos', and to be honest, i agreed with it. I also had a pent up desire to do an even more bombastic history project than the japan one, so i changed the plans, cancelled the remaining short-medium projects, and started on history of the entire world. Something you may or may not know about the history of the world- the world has a lot of history. so, to put it all into 1 video is probably impossible, so i knew i was taking on something that might be impossible. but i wanted to do it anyway. so first i had to *learn* the history of the entire world. which also takes a long time. research and writing took all summer, and i reached the end of the writing by about September 7, 2016. One of the things i had been thinking during the writing process, is a 2D equirectangular projected map is probably not gonna work for this. i should really get it on a 3D globe. but i didn't have the tools for that. so during most of september i was experimenting with various 3D tools to try to meet my 3D needs. i also began going through and developing the images that would be needed for the video, while also making many changes to the script. By the end of october i had most of this squared away, and around November 1st i was ready to begin the full video production. At this point i was determined to reach the end of the entire project by december 1st, and i nearly destroyed myself throughout november trying to meet this. but toward the end of november i realized this wasn't even close to possible. so i continued through december, through many of the most challenging parts of the video production, especially having to correct some problems with the 3D globe animations (which had been first done in october). finally made it to the end of the visual production by about february 7 (2017), and began on recording the final narration, and doing the final jingles, and then finally doing the score. the video was finally finished around may 10, 2017. By this time i knew very well that i really just need to do songs for the rest of my life. So i decided to skip the videos and just do audio songs, 1 per week. this went ok, but i soon realized that videos are very important. so around late june (2017) i started on 2 projects simultaneously: a freeform non-song video (hi, i'm steve) and a music video for one of the recently released audio songs (movie star). Working on 2 things at once is usually a recipe for failure, so i did then one at a time. steve first, then movie star. Then onward, to the next music video, 'outside'. this took about 6 weeks. I've never been pleased by the amount of time it takes to do these things. my prefered target for music videos would be 1 week, but to this day i've never been able to accompish this. Nearing the end of the 'outside' project, in late september (2017), i made a demand of myself that i MUST do these in 2 weeks. and i also felt it was necessary to do non-songs as well. So, alternate betwen non-songs and songs, and also, 1 out of every 2 songs should have live performance footage. So the next item would be a non-song, and, because i was able to make it shorter, i was able to do it just barely in 2 weeks. this was called 'soap tips' and was completed around oct 10, 2017. The next thing would have to be a song, and it would have to include live performance footage. Unfortunately this shattered all previous records for how long a music video should take, and this is probably because i hadn't appeared in live performance footage in such a long time that i couldn't stop myself from being incredibly particular for how things appear. i was horrified by the fact that that project ultimately took exactly the same amount of time as history of japan had taken (98 days, or 14 weeks.) it was finally completed in january, 2018. the target of course was 2 weeks, but that was a hopeless failure. So my next revision of the plan, would be to do 2 weeks per video, but they don't have to be a song. because i knew song videos would take longer, probably because my standards for how long a song should be were somewhere around 2:30 to 3:30, where as the non-song videos could be as short as 1 minute or maybe even less. so i decided to just try 1 video per 2 weeks, not necessarily a song. I was able to succeed at this, just barely, with 2 non-song videos. But, of course, as fate would have it, i realized songs are incredibly important. So i decided to do a song next, i already knew i wanted to do 'and the day goes on', because that one had its writing completed (in 2016) and i thought it was a strong one that i was confident about. I decided 4 weeks would be a sensible target for that. it was an especially elegant target, because it was february, and in that year (most years) februrary is exactly 4 weeks, so that would put the release date on exactly the same day of the month as the previous. Unfortunately that proved again to be impossible. and it never helps that my standards usually continue to go up. I was very meticulous on most parts of the process. i finally was able to complete the video around april 25, 2018. i immediately moved on to start the next song project. It's worth mentioning what happens next, because that will help bring this into even more perspective for you. At the start of every song process, i first do a generalized idea having process, where i come up with brand new ideas for songs. I usually do about 5 or 10, THEN the song selection process begins, where those new ideas are put into the much larger pool of unfinished songs, and i select from the entire list. It looks like there were 9 new ideas created on april 26 and 27, 2018. What ended up being selected, for the next song, was none of those, it was one that was already in the broader list ('hello sexy pants'). But, of those new 9, many of those have been extremely strong contenders every time since, with many of them almost getting picked, and one of them being 'when i get older' which was picked later that year. To get back to your original question, i think one of the strongest factors in play here is the fact that it is impossible to do everything at the same time, although that would be extremely convenient for me

090240.question: i keep having ideas when it's hard to write them down (shower etc.) and if i do go to write the idea down i usually forget most of the details. and if i deliberately put myself into a situation where i can easily write things down (usually by having my ideas document open or by using an audio recorder), then i can't have ideas. it feels like it's only possible for me to either have ideas or remember them, but not both.
090240.answer: that's true, ideas come most easily when they would be harder to write down. There are 2 strategies for the shower. one strategy, if you think the idea is really that good, just get out of the shower and go write it down. Or, if you don't want to do that, here are some memory tricks. pretend you are explaining the idea to someone else, and start explaining it in as many technical ways as you can. Pretend you have to explain it to them so that they can reproduce the idea exactly, but, you are not allowed to actually demonstrate it. For example, if it's a sentence, say "the first word is ___, the second word is ____," etc... Count the words. remind yourself how many words there are. Say all the odd numbered words. Say all the even numbered words. Think of the first letter of each word, and put all those letters together. try to come up with an alternate sentence using the same starting letters. Try to access the idea in as many different ways as you can. If it is a musical idea, start thinking of the notation of it, imagine you are explaining the musical notation to someone else without singing it. List the notes in order. Count the notes. List the rhythmic values in order. If you don't know musical notation in this way, hopefully you have some other conceptual notation system you use to think about notes and time. What tempo is it? what song has a similar tempo? how many notes are in the first beat? how many notes are in the second beat? etc etc etc. Keep trying to access the idea on as many mental avenues as you can, and this will increase the likelyhood that you will be able to retrieve it. but really the best option is to just get out of the shower. Most other places besides the shower, try to carry a recording device with you, the most common one being a smart phone. and if you have that, then much of these techniques will not be necessary

090303.answer: you have to believe you made it up. not only that, but you have to also believe you are making it up, at the moment you are playing it. you have to believe you are improvising it. if your playing sounds scripted, try improvising for a while. 090334.question: i remember reading somewhere that you're self-taught as a musician, and aside from a keyboard you have a bass as well. who/what influences your bass playing style, and what advice would you give to a budding bass player?
090334.answer: songs, basically you want to get yourself as soon as possible into a role where you are providing the bass for a song. if you can't get together with other people to play together, (and most people probably can't), just go ahead and take your favorite song recordings and cut out the bass frequencies, and plug your bass into a speaker which DOES have bass frequencies, and play along. Examples of speakers with and without bass frequencies, so you know which ones to use for which-- has bass frequencies: bass amp, headphones, home stereo system does not have bass frequencies: laptop speaker, phone speaker, tablet speaker, speakers inside your computer monitor play the song on the speaker with no bass, and put your bass through a speaker with bass. now you are the bass player

090512.question: How did you predict 2020 in "just did a bad thing"? "All the things I'm supposed to do / and the places I'm supposed to go are cancelled" What is the real meaning behind this line?
090512.answer: things predict themselves. that's what i like about songwriting, it opens the door for things to do what they're gonna do here's what i think, as i'm analyzing it now: this is a classic case of the song being about itself. The starting point for that song was just the one line ('just did a bad thing'), with really no indication of any sort of form or anything. Half way through the first section, it already seems to ditch out of the original paradigm slightly ('wondering what it is, etc'), it slips into the major key, and just,... no sort of repeating figure has been established. so far everything seems to be a special-case scenario. Then when it hits the next stanza, (bad day, bad year), we've already broken from what it had done in the first stanza. (the first stanza had the 'regret' line, which is quite different from the first line, but in the second stanza, the first two lines essentially are the same as each other), so for many reasons, at this point, (after 'bad year'), it's very clear that there is NO established pattern. we are free to roam. And it's likely at this point that i was feeling stuck, because really there's just too many possibilities. I was probably running through what i had so far, thinking i would get clues about the future (of the song) from the past (in the song). And that's just not gonna happen, because really what should probably happen is it should probably get out and GO somewhere it hasn't gone yet. So, looking at what did come next, the 'cancelled' line, this is a perfect way of expressing that everything you might have expected was going to happen (based on what happened so far) in the song, will probably not happen. And, sure enough, immediately after this, it transitions into a totally new key, and a new paradigm entirely. So basically the reason for that line is to shake off the previous paradigm (bad things, etc), because we gotta get away and jump into a whole new territory. (the 'game' section, etc). As far as anything having resemblence to future world events, well, this is always more likely to happen the more songs i write. when making a case that something predicted something, you can always ignore the ones that didn't fit. such as 'at the airport terminal' which certainly does not predict 2020

090776.question: what is the best way to learn new songs on the piano for someone who can read sheet music but at a slow speed?
090776.answer: spend more quality time with the instrument, without reading. start learning to use it to express your feelings. then try to figure out some songs, also without reading. 090777.question: How do you make all your songs so unique? Every artist has their own style, including you, but your songs are always distinguishable from each other.

However there is nothing to really stop the songs from being produced the same way..... sometimes i promise to use different tools from what i used on the previous songs. but .... producing songs is such an intense thing, i usually end up needing all the tools. so at that point all i can do is kind of hope and pray that the tools got used in a slightly different order

090841.question: is johnny b goode 84 bpm or 168 bpm? how?
090841.answer: that's gonna be the faster one. in my opinion, because "on 2 and 4" is such a famous phrase in our society, i've concluded that i think the tempo should be made to fit that whenever possible. So when there is any type of snare sound, clap sound, or strong mid-high percussion sound, occuring repeatedly on anything that could be percieved as beats 2 and 4 (out of 4), this should be assumed to be what's called the 'backbeat', and therefore on 2 and 4

How do you feel about that interpretation? I know you're probably going to say something along the lines of "there are no wrong interpretations" but is this one that you intended or accounted for? While I agree that your music does have that facet, I personally feel like there is so much more to it than some seem to give you credit for. It saddens me a bit when I see your music being written off like that but then again maybe I'm taking it too seriously as well?
090868.answer: that seems like a pretty negative interpretation, so i am going to either assume it is your interpretation, or you are deliberately trying to deliver negative feedback to me no You are playing a classic game of 'good cop, bad cop', where you assure me that you like me more than anyone else does

090898.question: Hello. I wanted to start learning music, is there any instrument you would recommend? Thank you if you decide to answer this
090898.answer: your voice is good because you can use words and it's almost directly connected to your brain. a keyboard might be good because it has all the notes spread out in order, and you can play multiple notes at the same time (chords) which your voice can't do. and it's a good way to really learn all the notes. Also keyboards can interface very well with computers, so that is a huge gateway to a lot of possibilities in the modern world. On the other hand, guitars are a very interesting alternative to keyboards. they have a much more readily acoustic quality, although it is not as easy to pick and choose exactly what notes you want to use

091106.question: 1.8.21 11:03 pm In that case, how about you change the name of "Stupid Song" to "i wanna be stupid" so less people confuse it with "The Stupid Song"?
091106.answer: because, the way that song feels, (the one about holding on to what you've got, etc etc) it just feels like a song that should be called "The ____ Song". this is strange, because i think i had to actually call that one "Stupid Song", but that one definitely feels like it should be called "The Stupid Song". You would think the other one should then be called "Stupid Song", because in fact, that other one (hold my hand / touch my face, etc) seems like more of just "a stupid song". that is how i think of that one. But, because of the silly nature of that song, as part of the sillyness, it becomes very important to call that one "The Stupid Song", to bring it that sense of conviction in its stupidness. So the truth is that the best title for both songs is "The Stupid Song". which is a mildly unfortunate coincidence, for the sake of the catalog

091117.question: Do you find that you can listen to stuff you have written and enjoy it/appreciate things? Or do you more tend to focus on the things that you could improve/did wrong/didn't know at the time? On a semi-related note, artistry. What the hell is it and how do you become bold enough to actually create shit that's you? The more I continue to live, the more I feel like I'm just an interpreter and can't really achieve a level of originality that is meaningful or worthwhile. I know I'm capable of writing. I've done it. But i also paralyze myself with the fear that what I write won't be world-altering, which of course it won't be - i haven't done a lot of writing so I don't have the practice. But then I don't practice writing as much as I should because I'm scared my stuff won't be world-altering. And then it feels like it reflects on me. I tend to hide on the arranger side because I can feel safe in the comfort of someone else's writing. If my shit don't s lap, well, I can't be entirely to blame, it's not my tune. But if my original shit don't slap . guess that means I just don't slap as a musician/human. Any thoughts or advice on how to exist and create? (P.S. Sorry for the length, your wisdom inspires me)
091117.answer: sometimes sometimes at some point, if you still can't seem to do it, just start doing anything you can. you may be surprised how quickly you realize you can actually do everything a fun fact about world-altering: it's actually possible to do certain things that seem so NON world altering, that it actually seems world-altering in its level of non-world-altering. Which therefore immediately creates quite an earth-shattering feeling, as it becomes clear that you've just altered the world by seemingly not altering it well that's fair, because some people only write and they're gonna need arrangers so far you are doing pretty good

091217.answer: the first thing is to figure out if that piece is the beginning or not the beginning. If it's the beginning, then, run through it and see if you know what comes next. if it's not the beginning then you're kinda fucked. 091844.question: you say that you try not to use nonsensical lyrics, yet on the surface some of your lyrics are easy to interpret as nonsensical, so i'm curious. what was the meaning behind the first verse of "i'm best friends with my own front door"?
091844.answer: i'm curious if you are just reading them, with no music. they're not guaranteed to work like that basically i was starting on a new experiment: finish an entire music video in 2 weeks or die trying. i was sick of failure, i had been trying to do this and kept failing. the previous several videos all took 8 weeks or more. and i just was so desperate and felt like my life was passing me by, so i just snapped and demanded myself to succeed at 2 weeks. So i'm going through the (long) list of songs and song ideas to choose from, and, ...... it's just not working. i'm going through the list for hours, not finding one i want to do. So at some point, my brain just said "what would the song you Want to do now sound like?" and spontaneously the first line hit me, and i knew immediately that that would be the next song. So i already know it feels right, seems right, means very much to me, etc, but, when i think about it i can also explain why this is. It's like i'm developing a friendliness toward the idea of just... walking out the front door. Just being honest with my situation, ... etc. and picking this next song should be something as easy as just opening the front door, in a friendly manner. Now the second line, again this all came to me instinctually, but i'm just trying to think about it now and explain it.... the second line ('i just closed it but it's opening more') .... this gets deeper because there is the feeling that even if i've failed to notice how easy things could be, ... the door is actually opening on its own. We all know we have the tendency to sometimes overlook the friendly and obvious choices in life, so i think this line gives me a pretty strong feeling because it's like it's saying, even if you miss it, the opportunity will grow more to make you notice it. And the next 2 lines, ('then the cops came and they sent me to jail, but tomorrow i'm gonna open it again'), and again this is not supposed to necessarily work good without the music. so please take this only in the context of the way it sounds in the song. So these 2 lines seem to be basically doubling down on this optimism: the 3rd line is like "nope, youre gonna get punished for taking the easy route", then the 4th line shows determination to overcome this. Another bit of optimism is tucked in here also because most jails don't let you open the door. So you're just saying, tomorrow you're gonna get another chance to easily and friendily open a door that was previously assumed to be unopenable.

091908.question: When people say to me "your mixes sounds thin/muddy because of the arrangement", I kind of understand where they're coming from - frequencies clash, they can't occupy the same space etc etc. But is this what people really mean by "arrangement"? Because I feel like there's gotta be more to it. Can you shed light on this? What is a "bad" arrangement and what is a "good" arrangement?
091908.answer: in terms of sound clarity, basically you just want to get as much power out of as few sounds as you can. when it gets too cluttered, it turns to mud. But, when you have less, sometimes it may feel like you need more power. it's a paradox that sometimes feels like it takes a lifetime to overcome. but everyone gets better at this, the more they do it. The issue goes back further than arranging, ..... ultimately it goes back to the songwriting. if you write a song good enough, it's almost impossible to fuck it up later

092014.question: i have been making music as a hobby since March last year, and I frequently find myself getting attached to the verse chorus verse chorus bridge chorus structure. i have tried really hard to do something different because i am getting really bored of it. whenever i do something different, i'm just not happy with the results. either that, or i get stuck in nowhere. any ideas on how to overcome this? also, i dont know a lot of music theory. do you think spending time on learning music theory could help? thanks!
092014.answer: check all the songs you listen to. see if any of them do something besides that form. See if there are any songs you really really like, that don't follow that form. figure out what it does instead. figure out what you want to call that. Just check out all the songs you know and see what kind of roadmap they're using. Just take some time and enjoy some different road maps. eventually they will all come out in your writing if you've been making music, then you are the one with the theories. Maybe it's time for you to teach those theories.......

092063.question: what is your selection process for songs?
092063.answer: first, generate some entirely new ones. then when i'm done doing that, then, go through the entire list of everything and find ones that i would be excited about doing, and put those in a 'finalists' list. like the play-offs, in sports. top 20 or 30. Then, i actually start working on the writing for some of those, without choosing yet. Then i set a hard deadline, sometime in the next 24 hours, to decide which will be the next one to be finished, recorded, vidified etc. It gets pretty painful toward the end, and sometimes there is a lot of feelings of remorse and dread the next day. but in the end i have to trust the system because it's the best system i have

092096.question: Would you try to draft a song in a music notation software (like Sibelius, Finale, Musescore, etc.)?

092489.question: Do you start with melodies or chord progressions or both? I'm having trouble sorta matching them up. I can write cool chord progressions but melodies get a little weird.
092489.answer: the lyric/melody and chords are written at exactly the same time. the lyric/melody are usually the driver, with the chords also pasted to it. so all 3 are in the driver's seat together if they are made at the same time then they have to be matched up. or else they wouldn't get made try starting with the melody, with words on it. Actually, forget that, ..... try this. imagine a scene in your mind. imagine a situation, in life. Any situation. just make something up. then sing something about it, coming up with the words and the melody at the exact same time, according to what it felt like to be in the situation you imagined. Then very quickly after that, you can add chords to what you sang, which i'm sure you know how to do by now

092563.question: Once you have a melody and a chord progression that you like (like a loop, or an A section), how do you go about making a transition into a new section (voice leading? music theory tool? Wild guessing? Wikipedia?)? THANK YOU!
092563.answer: i don't use loops do a fresh run-through from the beginning, at the exact tempo. the more refreshed you are, the better this will work. It works the best if you haven't heard the song in a day. do a fresh run-through, and then just as you start to approach the end of what you have, that is when lightning will strike, if it does. listen very closely in that moment, and try to gather as many details as you can about what you think you are hearing next. Another trick which often produces results is to imagine the song is taking place in a scene. imagine a visual story for the song to take place in. Also another thing i almost forgot to mention, in case you are not doing already, try to use words/language for this

092803.question: I'm a high school music teacher, and I get the sense that you avoid talking about your school years because you've realized what pretty much every musician needs to realize at one point or another if they are going to improve their musicianship. That the only person who can improve your musicianship is you. You have to the do the work, the ear training, the practicing, the time song writing and creating. So here's my question(s). How did you develop your work ethic for creating music? Did people in your life have an influence on you developing this skill? What do you think music teachers could be doing better to try and foster this skill in other people?
092803.answer: it's similar to the way a person might develop a habit of using crack-cocaine, except instead of 1 drug it's more like 1000, because there is at least 1000 different ways to become totally and deeply hooked into music i was able to hear a lot of music on records (and through the television of course, paired with visuals in such a way that i may not even realize until decades later just how crucial the audio-visual relationship is) and i will confess i also had access to a piano/keyboard instrument, and a drum set. There were also guitars around, but i've always been a bit overwhelmed/intimitated by guitars. having an extremely early start, it was pretty natural to find myself in many many personal and professional music relationships with peers (well at first it was usually people much older than me because i was so young to start) what i think is the best approach, for me personally, is to write and record the best songs i can. if i can get them good enough, then maybe that will help someone else hear just a glimpse of what may be possible, just the way i might have heard someone else before, even if it's just for 7 seconds coming out of a car window going around the corner

092952.question: I struggle between choosing to spend my time coming up with new ideas or finish existing ones that I started. I want to have a goal of 1 new musical idea per *reasonable amount of time*, but I don't know how to prioritize between investing time into new things when I have ideas outstanding that need attention. Do you have any suggestions/have you experienced this? thanks
092952.answer: basically what i did, when i was first in your situation, is to just keep coming up with new ideas. let them pile up. This is probably because i may have had a fear of not having enough ideas. Then it rapidly became a problem. Another thing i began doing is writing songs entirely on paper, and i would demand to finish the whole thing in 1 session. That's one way of dealing with it. so i wrote more and more and more. Sometimes they wouldn't get finished, sometimes they would. Usually if it was shorter, it would get finished. but they all got put into the list regardless. more years went by with more writing like this. It was more rare that i would ever record any of them. Eventually when the problem became even more serious, i finally found a way to work on the existing ideas. This is a whole separate task from generating new ideas, and i still consider them separate. For a couple years i ONLY did 'middle writing', which is where i work on existing ideas. Then a few months later, as i was getting ready to start recording some of them, i did a few weeks of finishing, just finishing writing for songs. I could talk for years about the different systems i've used for SELECTING which ones to work on. And this is not even to discuss selections for the recording process, which you didn't ask about. Eventually as enough years go by, you start to feel your life running out, so you probably take drastic measures. Nowadays, for me this is how it works: new ideas can come any time, that's always true. Sometimes they even come in dreams. So i catch them whenever they arrive, and i don't really do a writing session at that time because it's usually not the right time. but you just try to catch as much as you can. That's totally separate from any writing process or work process. Separately from that, it is a linear process of working toward the item i am releasing next, and i work on that 1 item until it's done. For songs, first what i do, at the beginning of a project, i do a round of new song idea generation, but this is NOT necessarily promising that any of these will be the one that's used. This is just to ensure that i am giving myself a chance to generate new ideas, which might have a chance of getting picked. So i generate some new ideas, maybe 10 or 15. Sometimes i use various different methods, just to make sure i've given myself a chance to try various things. Then, when that's done, i do song 'selection', which is where i'm going to choose which one is going to be recorded, for the next release. This selection is made from the ENTIRE list, which includes the new ones but also includes all the other ones, which are all at various levels of completion (writing). Once a selection is made, then it's quite simple. I finish the writing all the way, first, then record it, all the way. then make the video, all the way. I should clarify that this procedure didn't become solidified until after many many many years of ambiguity which may be similar to what you are going through now

093003.question: I teach singer/songwriters and I get a lot of the beginner songwriters coming to me and saying stuff like "I just don't know how to get the pieces of the song together. I don't know how it's supposed to sound. Why doesn't my song have a longer chorus? My phrases are too short! Blah blah blah" and they make these statements about the entirety of their work as if their songs need to be XYZ kind of way. It's like they want me to tell them that there's a RIGHT and a WRONG way to make a song good. And when I tell them that it sounds like they're asking for an acceptable formula, their eyes kind of glaze over. They say "I don't want my songs to be formulaic! I just want to know the right way to write a song" but in my mind those are the same thing. What I've told them is this - make up your own formula for an individual song. However you want the patterns to be and then fit your segments into the formula YOU create. I'm hoping at a minimum this will make t hem focu s more on their own instincts and less on right and wrong. But I can't tell. What do you think I should tell them?
093003.answer: reverse psychology can go a long way. Tell them to try to write it wrong. it's amazing how quickly it becomes very right

093039.question: What inspired "the road"? It's surreal but it still feels like it's grounded in something.
093039.answer: during 2009 and 2010 especially, i was doing this thing where i would write songs on paper only, with no instrument. Just start at the beginning and see where it goes. i wrote a lot of songs that way. i guess you could call it 'chain writing', or 'train writing', because the whole thing is written in order. And it's all done on the chart, on paper. Then around 2011 i got envious of more 'normal' songs, so i finally learned how to be organized enough to work on songs at an instrument, find a chorus first maybe, learn how to write what's before the chorus, you know, normal stuff. So i did a lot of that during 2011. Near the beginning of 2012, however, there was a day where i fondly remembered the joy of 'chain writing' so i did some of those. and 'the road' is one of them. So it is likely that the contents of the song somehow reflects the context of that situation

093093.question: 1. How did you evolve into 3D animating? 2. What font do you use for your videos? 3. How much time was your career in music?
093093.answer: first, i wrote a video about the history of the entire world. So i really needed to show the locations on a 3 dimensional globe. So then once i had cracked the ice on that skill set, i started to use tiny bits of 3D in every video after that. but then eventually i started to realize that i wasn't really giving myself enough time to give it a chance. Then one day when starting the music video i decided to start the whole thing in the 3D environment. well it blew my mind, to such a severe extent that it made me decide to take a giant and decisive leap into that realm regular so far it's been at least 25 years, but i'm going for way more than that

093095.answer: write it down, and read it. if this seems too hard to do, this might be a cool opportunity to work on reading skills. 093156.question: that I might be wrong) I'm gonna start from the most obvious part first I don't have enough time To say the things I wanna say To do the things I wanna do Or to be like you ---These 4 lines refer to how we are too busy to do the things we want, we aren't allowed to state our opinions freely, the line "or to be like you" may refer to how we compare ourselves to others I just want some time To express the things I feel Just to express the things I feel And believe them too --- This lines refers to how we often have our own opinions on some things, and we wanted to express them but can't. it also refers to cases where we d ebate wi th other people, and we started doubting our opinion and belives 2 + 2 has been 4 for So many darn years, oh Lord ---I think this refers to how we must live according to the rules created by society, while the "oh lord" part implies how we really want to break out from this cage I wanna write a song Oh, baby is that so wrong? ---I believe this refers to how we wanted to do something, but people would often try to stop us, even if the thing we're doing isn't bad I went down to the mall Then they closed down the mall Guess they don't want me going to the mall 'Cause I'm just too small ---This references on how sometimes people think we're to young to some stuff I just went online To explain the things I feel To express the things I mean And it f elt so real ---This refers to how we spent more time online than offline, and how our internet connection becomes more important Now I'm doing alright And I'm downright feeling okay It's the end of the world And I just can't wait --- Deppression? I know that you can relate ---Yes Then I built some trains And I'm travelling somewhere new It's a wonderful world, but Still no you It's a wonderful world for two ---This part describes our journey on finding happiness, we realize the world is beautiful, but we still can't find happiness (referenced by "still no you", you references happiness) And now for the main part, the la de da part And it goes La de da de da de da de day oh La de da de where did all the good times go? ( La de da de la da dee d um dom L a da de day When will you come back home? ---I believe that this part (and all the other la de da part) is referencing the idea of genuine happiness, happiness without reason. If we examine the lyrics, most of it consists of the word la de da de da, which really has no actual meaning (there's some explanation about the word "la di da" but I don't think Bill is referencing to that la di da) ---The tune (or the sound, music, I don't know what you actually call them) is a joyful expression. The la de da part sounds happy. Combine this with the meaningless of the lyrics, this means happiness without reason. ---Genuine happiness is actually rare this days. Yes, we often feel happy, like when we just won a game match, or we get a promotion at work, but that happiness is only temporary. If the condition changes (like we lose the next game, or someone accidentally hit our car when we're going home from work) we will no longer be happy ---Gen uine happiness, on the other hand, doesn't have a reason. it's being happy simply because we existed. It's a feeling of being grateful because we're still here, regardless on the situation. This is what we all wanted. The words "When will you come back home" expresses our search for this happiness, as we continue to wait for happiness to come to us. The lines Then I built some trains And I'm travelling somewhere new It's a wonderful world, but Still no you It's a wonderful world for two expresses our believes that if we have wealth, career, love, fame, or all those other things, we can be genuinely happy, but that isn't true. we don't need all of that. Genuine happiness is as simple as being happy, but we struggle to find that, like how we don't understand simple words like "la de da de yo" Just got home got no home La de da d-de where did it go? Oh no I can't go home. --- I believe this is an exp ression on how we believe that we don't have happiness, when it's really it's just there. Kinda like how Bill wrote "Got no home" While he, definitely, have a home. We believe we don't have happiness, while it's really just there, waiting us to come back home. What do you think about my analysis? DId I miss your point completely?
093156.answer: that could be true. When i first wrote that, i was probably making an excuse for the song not being good enough. the original version of that was "i don't have enough time to write the song i want to sing, so please don't judge me one little bit". then, 2 years later, i re-wrote it with possibly slightly more experienced songwriting abilities for me this was just another extrapolation of my previous sentiment, because this part wasn't there in the original. it jumped straight to the 2+2 part after "please don't judge me one little bit" what i was probably thinking was, songwriting apparently has been possible for many many years, and the reason i think i know this is because a lot of songs exist i just wanted to write songs, and i couldn't really figure out why it was more difficult than i expected, considering the fact that i already had multiple decades of musical experience prior to that point, in addition to having written dozens of songs already, many years before that the 'too small' line is the worst line in the song. it is literally just a rhyme. horrible. i am against doing this. it breaks one of my best rules of songwriting, which is don't do that. The triple mall line(s), however, i stand behind. And it's basically my way of plowing fearlessly into the second verse. Think of it this way ........ i had just selected this song the day before, to be the next one that's recorded, and i was having major remorse about it (despite having been very diligent in the song selection). I really was feeling down about the whole thing, and i had already changed my mind about it and chose to do a much sadder and slower song instead. But then i was doubting that one just as much, so, i was actually at the barber and i was waiting for a hair cut, and i was trying to comprehend what went wrong in the song choice. So i came back to thinking about this 'la de da' song. At the time, the song was only written up until the end of the first chorus. so i guess i just briefly posed the question, 'what if i COULD do this one.... and what would the second verse most likely be, if i did it' and just as i was getting into the barber chair, the first 3 mall lines assaulted me right in the face. And i was immediately convinced that that seals the deal for the song choice, but that particular burst of writing went no further. and i was left to toil in the mud when i got home to try to complete the phrase. i made a bad decision, and i suppose i tried to mask it with background vocal arrangements i think, if you are talking about the last line, i think it is playing on the fact that the internet is real, while also using a phrase like "it felt so real" which is a phrase commonly associated with things that *might* not be real. so i was attempting to provide a little bit of intrigue there. Also one thing you forgot to mention was that i switched the words in the more common phrases 'explain the things i mean' and 'express the things i feel'. i switched the verbs, to see if it means something slightly different. turns out it does no, this is just meant to provide an alternate flavor of the line in the corresponding position in the verse before this. which you conveniently did not mention yet it seems to be fairly common for people to make casual conversation about the world being all wrong you mentioned this out of order, but this comes after the "just too small" line. Perhaps the 'built some trains', 'traveling somewhere new' was my way getaway scheme, to escape from the blandness of the previous line. Or just assuming the mall was not a viable option. it is a natural progression to take a train somewhere else.... but with 10,000 bonus points for building your own train. When the subject of 'traveling somewhere new' comes up, it becomes impossible not to mention how wonderful the world is. when you think of all the possible places you could go. But then, when realizing that, the NEXT thing to immediately realize is it would be nice to have some companionship as well. OR, there is also a double meaning to 'still no you' line, it could also mean the world IS "no you". like, it's still doesn't compare to you. That's just in case maybe you took a look around at the world and still think it's not as good as it could be. so in that case you would be singing TO something which you think could be even better than the world. So in that moment, the line seems to mean those 2 things. But when the next line hits ('wonderful world for 2') i think it becomes more clear that it actually meant the first thing the lines immediately before this were basically begging to write a song. we have already essentially looked in the mirror and stated the wish 3 times, pretty much there is nowhere else to go but to actually do it. "La de da" etc. would be a meta characterization of a song being written Well i think it's clear that there was a very strong previous desire to write a song, and it seems clear when the chorus hits that this is actually happening. So i think that is a pretty good reason THAT'S BECAUSE YOU CONVENIENTLY TOOK THE MELODY AWAY. LIKE FOR FOOD, DO YOU THINK A PLATE HAS MEANING i think the problem is you are blatantly ignoring all the meaning could be true i think it's really easy to understand if it's together with the melody, and, with the context of the previous part of the song basically what this is about is ending the song. I already tried 2 other endings which seemed more obvious, and they just weren't working for me. so i tried kicking it into a barren wasteland real quick, to see where it takes me. Much more interesting results, i thought about 30%. However, one of the most powerful things about music and songs is the ability to have multiple meanings. So the meanings you've found in it are certainly just as real, but, what seemed strange to me was when you tried to claim certain things were meaningless while you were clearly finding meaning in it. just seemed a little hypocritical

093195.question: i think one of the things that's so compelling and satisfying about your music video style, and your musical style for that matter, re-watching 'here comes the sun' for the 15th time or whatever, is how understated a lot of things are, but also how overt and flashy certain things are. like, you'll have little moments that i don't even think about after several viewings, but then i see and i'm like, that's such a nice little moment, a little clip in the background of you doing a little finger wave with your hand or a little random stick figure guy climbing for a second or whatever. that's part of what's so incredible about your style is you have a very acute sense of how to keep things moving, not lingering too long on something, almost cutting things off before they have a chance to be boring, but just long enough to have an impact. it's very scintillating, if i'm allowed to use that word. anyways i hope your new music video is going well and you're doing go od in general. you're one of the most inspiring modern musicians/artists to me and it's really humbling and exciting to be alive at the same time as you. i wish you all the success and happiness that you can handle.

Also, when you are writing, how do you tell the difference between a forced rhyme and one that feels "right"? Sorry for all the questions, thanks in advance if you answer any of these, and thank you for being an incredibly bright light in this world!
093269.answer: that's not me doing rhymes. rhymes can be naturally found in nature, and i've found that they have their best effects when you don't try to search for them. But, that's not all: if you try to "make" rhymes, not only you could ruin the meaning of the words, but you'll also destroy any chance for the lines to be interesting lengths, or start and end at interesting times yes just listen and see how it feels

093338.question: there seems to be a recurring pattern with your song lyrics in that many songs are about themselves. does "moon cheese" fit into this as well? maybe tasting represents achieving the song's full potential, if you were doubting yourself at the time.
093338.answer: it probably does the whole point of that song, from the start, is the title. i was envious of other songs (probably country songs) which have a title which already has some cleverness baked right in. so i thought of one, "the moon is made of cheese (but i can't taste it)". so just went from there and tried to continue the game. you can't taste it, but you like the way the texture feels when you lick the surface. Makes perfect sense, but is also completely ridiculous. so the next line "the rumors start to go round the world that i'm crazy" well of course, because you're licking the moon. but no, instead, it's "becaususe you can't taste the cheese". so the fun score, for me, continues to be upheld up to that point. Next stanza, start with a line to echo the same theme as the first. famous phrase ('the grass is always green') then change it ('but i just changed it'). From this point, the key changes start to play an even more significant role, but, the game remains the same. i'm simply in search of quality songwriting

093340.question: Do you have any advice to someone who wants to write complete songs (with backing and harmonies and bridges) solo? How do you start your writing process? I have lots of ideas that I've recorded but I'm not really sure how to put them together.
093340.answer: keep a journal. this could be a long journey i pick an idea from the list if they weren't written together, then they probably are not part of the same song. i think if you try to put them together they may look like awkward surgery. So, pick 1, and then 'play doctor' with it. give it a diagnosis. Is it the beginning of the song? is it not the beginning of the song? is it a 'chorus'? is it not a chorus? What does this idea mean to you? try to remember everything about the circumstances of coming up with it. This should lead you to your next decision about what it needs. Another thing that i should mention about the way i do it, i always write the entire song all the way through before even touching the production process. I know that not everyone does it this way, but, i've found out, to play to my strengths it's important to remain as nimble as possible during the writing process, and that means not trying to actually produce it while writing. i am a 'write first' person, then produce what i wrote. Also another thing i should mention, i was in your situation (wanting to produce entire songs myself) and i knew i was qualified, because i had already been playing multiple instruments for at least 10 or 15 years before, so i thought it should be easy. but unfortunately it took me at least 10 MORE years after that before i really felt like i could comfortably get the entire job done. actually i'm still not really there yet. But who knows ..... maybe you will find a way to make things.... simpler

093408.question: how to build a chair?
093408.answer: Remove all parts from the carton and separate them into part number groups as indicated in the parts list. To begin assembly, place the 5-star base upside down and insert casters into the bottom of base. Turn the base right side up on the floor and insert the cylinder into the center hole on the base. Place the telescoping cover over the the cylinder and rest it on the base. Attach the seat plate to the bottom of the seat cushion (with front of seat plate facing the front of the seat cushion) by using 15/8" screws into the front holes of the seat plate and 7/8" screws into the rear holes of the seat plate and tighten the screws. Align the back cushion with the seat cushion by positioning the back support plate over the seat plate with 11/4" screws. Do not tighten the screws completely. Attach the arms respectively on each side onto the bottom of the seat cushion and the sides of back cushion by using 11/2" screws. Tighten all the screws. Remember to tighten the screws on the back support plate. Place the plastic caps into the two arm holes on each arm. Place the assembled chair on top of the cylinder and press down until fully engaged. Periodically (every 90 days) make sure that the screws are still fully tightened.

093419.question: Were you good at writing assignments in school? Because I'm always too horrified to do them; like everybody just does them as if it's the same as putting together cars on an assembly line but I can't think of the assignments like that, like I can't write something unless I'm sure it's true and meaningful. I guess ideally, I should be able to do that in a timely manner but I just can't, or at least I'm too scared to try. And the classic advice I always get is to not care too much about writing something good, but it just hurts to meaninglessly write for the sake of writing, like what's the point of being a human if you can't create anything with significance? Also it's not like the work that everyone else produces is shitty, it's actually very good which means that if I take the assembly-line approach, not only will the act of it feel horrible, but its product will be worse than what everyone else is somehow able to create with the same method. I dunno, I guess I'm asking this because you're definitely someone who makes meaningful content and well, you normally turn it out on a regular basis, so maybe you have some advice on how to accomplish this and perhaps on how you were able to these assignments back when you were in school. Thanks for reading this, I'm sorry if most of it is just a rant.
093419.answer: clearly you are a writer, as seen above. I think it's worth looking into re-negotiating your contract with your producer (the one giving you the assignments). Make sure you both understand each other's goals in this, and then evaluate if you would both like to keep working with each other

093436.question: I wrote a short instrumental piece with no regard to music theory--I didn't even give it a set time signature--last week and sent it to a friend of mine, who really seemed to like it. at first, I thought that was just their way of being supportive, but I later sent it to someone who actually knows music theory, and they also seemed to like it. I've tried writing pieces since then, and I've written a couple, but they're nowhere near the length and complexity of my first one, which wasn't very long or complex to begin with. my question is this: do you ever fear that the latest song you wrote was just based on dumb luck and might be the last good one? if so, how do you cope? if not, HOW? anyway, I hope your day's going well
093436.answer: no i've seen how rampantly contagious the forces of music are. over and over and over again, year after year after year after year after year (etc). It's like rainstorms. there's always another huge rainstorm. meteorologists have discovered this

093562.question: Do you use traditional classical music theory or jazz theory? Have you come up with your own system? If so, how does it work?
093562.answer: which is the one where you get to have notes and chords etc yes but, it is close cousins with the system generally used on the 'Earth' planet, over the course of the past 300 years or so eternally mysterious as music remains to this day, one thing i'm sure of is: the core principle seems to be about 'making patterns and breaking them'. This seems to apply to more than just music. But, what music adds to this, in addition, is pitches, which clearly have some nice relationships, which help to enrich the pattern making/breaking process to a level that is so deeply subliminal i feel you could spend 1000 lifetimes trying to figure out exactly how the heck it actually works. But, again, what i will say is, regardless of what seems 'known' or 'unknown', or 'right' or 'wrong', it becomes unnecessary to choose between the two, because what seems to always power the whole thing is this 'making patterns and breaking them' phenomenon. so given that, finding what's "right" and "wrong" becomes an ellusive chase which never yields a static answer. you just have to keep playing the game. which also happens to be very serious

093583.question: Hi Bill, I've been writing a song, and I got to a point where I think there should be a chorus next, but I have no idea how I should continue the song into one. How do I write a chorus from what I've already written?
093583.answer: coming up with these things is like lightning striking. You can't really guarantee that it happens, but, i can tell you everything i know so far about this. 1. it's most likely to happen when you run through the song, from the beginning, at the right tempo, without stopping 2. it gets more and more likely for it to happen the longer time it's been since you've heard the song. 3. this is unfortunate, because it's very time consuming to keep waiting until you haven't heard the song in a while, every time you hear it 4. try walking to the door of the room you are in, touching the door handle, and then returning to the instrument (or demo-recording you are working with) and do a run through. this may be an artificial way to help 'reset' if you don't have time to wait 5. if you're just not getting it, try to make categories of things, and try to rule them out. 6. for example, try continuing it to be the same as what came before. Hopefully you will get a strong signal "yes" or "no" from trying this. then you can rule that out, or in 7. try going to the most normal chord you haven't used yet. for example, if your verse is full of C and F chords, try G and see what happens 8. try something with dense melody/lyric (wordy). hopefully that will give you a strong 'yes' or 'no' signal 9. try something with very few words. see if you can rule that out or in 10. keep trying to categorically prove or dis-prove that a certain strategy is right or wrong 11. i forgot the most important thing which i should have said first, imagine a scene where your song takes place. then name something that could happen next. i should have mentioned this one first because it's probably the one that's most likely to work

093635.question: After listening many many times I've started noticing that the part that enjoy and makes me smile the most in "Here comes the Sun" is the part after "I can't explain the way I'm feeling" where you start mumbling the melody, and I was quite surprised by that fact because as a songwriter I always thought writing something meaningful brought out more emotions into a song. Do you think sometimes saying nothing can bring more emotions then actually saying something, do you think it can make the qualities of a song shine more and did you intend for that part to make someone feel that way or was it just a coincidence.
093635.answer: right. it does mean something. i've started the section with an instrumental riff, (no words), then jumped into lyric saying "and i can't explain the way that i'm feeling", which correlates together because i've done a wordless riff, then justifying that by saying "and i can't explain", so we've essentially established that we're blending the lyric and non-lyric, while the lyrics are actually referencing this. Then the next 2 lines (which are the ones you are talking about) are entirely in context with this, as we sing another lyricless melody and then explain that we're 'putting it into words', while also doing just that (putting it into words). Also, in addition, the line after that is "send it all over the world" which if you do not think has meaning i would be glad to spend every day of my life in court with you to explain that it does. Also the first thing you said was that this section makes you smile a lot, so i would be curious to know in what world is happiness not meaningful my songs are actually created by a random noise generator. that's why they sound like a steady hiss. any resemblence to the sound of words or music would be a huge coincidence

093672.question: hey bill, on one of your interview you talked about how pretty much every piece of software should have shortcuts for everything... reaper daw has that, along with scripting too... just wanted to let you know...
093672.answer: i've retracted that sentiment once i realized how many keyboards you'd need to make that work. But, i now firmly believe that all programs need to be scriptable, so that if you do choose to have a million keyboards, you can make use of them, and customize your workflow yes i know. i really need to switch to it. unfortunately there's never a good time to put the production schedule on pause for several more months. in the meantime, if anyone out there is in the mood to help me find some commands (from xraym's resources, probably) that would be helpful. Here's a major one: how to select the midi note nearest to the playhead, regardless of what track it's on, and play the sound of that note. then another script to travel to the next midi note forward in time, regardless of track, and play the sound of that one. Then another script to select the track of that note, and open the midi editor, with that note selected, and visible on the screen with a reasonable zoom range

093676.question: i always that that when you said "i'm just trying to be reasonable" that you were joking around. but, the way you said it in an interview seemed like you were actually being serious. some of your other answers to a similar question confused me. but, as of now i think it just means that you're getting by just trying to make something. it's just what came to you in the moment using the tools that you had. and, you just kept adding to what you knew and what came naturally. and, that's what being reasonable means, right? it's just a linear progression of what you have, know, and do creatively. it's my perception at the moment. does that seem like something you'd agree with?
093676.answer: it's sort of like when you are in a room, and you want to go to the next room. and there appears to be a door going between them. the first thing to try, might be to go through that door. that's sort of an example of what i might consider reasonable. 093687.question: Hey, Bill. So, I've reached that point in life in which I should know where I'm heading for, but I don't. I'm seventeen and apparently yesterday I couldn't choose what I'd have for lunch, but today I'm supposed to decide what to do for the rest of my life? And I've had this idea in the back of my mind for years, but I feel like I used to be scared of not knowing what to do and now I'm just kinda scared of knowing I don't want to do anything. Growing up, I've developed real interst in mathematics and languages, and I always thought I'd do something related to one of these areas. But now that I actually have to choose, I don't want either. I live in a developing country and everything is focused in applicability: maths and languages courses are too much about applied knowledge, never seen as pure areas of study. The reason why I fell in love with maths and languages in the first place was by overanalyzing things that have no real impact in the world: I liked that they were beautiful on their own, with no need to ever be used. And the prospects for me are really negative from this point on, because I feel like every college I go to and every job available for me will be quite the opposite of that. I wish I lived in the US or Europe where pure sciences actually exist, but I don't, and I can't afford to go these places. I feel like there's nothing I want to do with the rest of my life, and yet my parents say I have to choose soon because I gotta make money somehow. Anyway, I know this completely out of the scope of this page, I just really needed someone to talk to. I guess my question is "what should I do given that I'm a broken piece in the machine of human existence and don't seem to have any use to anyone or be able to perform any useful service to humanity, however small?"
093687.answer: there's no reason you should have to do that today. You may have known some of it since you were 6, and you may not find some of it until you are 96 you don't have to choose. those are both cool things, and they are allowed to be in your life, as much or little as you want i think you will still get a chance to do many things with your life, besides the things you do for employment. Sure, make some decisions on that now, but just make the best decision you can, based on the information you have. even if if you don't have all the information. Because you are obviously still missing at least half of the information. most people are. but you will find a lot of that information along the way. And either one you choose, you'll probably learn something. and also keep in mind that some of the most powerful things to be learned, may come from outside the 'curriculum' just taking a quick glance at the big picture here, just on the page here, it appears you seem to have some writing skills. which i can guarantee is a useful skill, in many many ways, and is still alive and thriving especially now in the internet age

093718.question: um okay so hi person I look up to quite a bit idk if you'll see this but I kinda need some life advice and I don't know who else I can talk to but uhhh: I've always known that I am the kind of person who HAS to be producing some kind of creative output, whether it's something like art or dancing or getting a job... like I just kind of have to DO something with my life you know?? the problem is that I'm not skilled in any sort of particular area and I know that I need to pick something to do and then stick to it but I just don't know what??? I consume and consume all the sights and events and media around me and I have all of these thoughts and desire to do SOMETHING but I can't figure out what to channel it into. Once I figure out what I should be doing I know I'll put my blood, sweat, and tears into it but I just can't find a starting point. I'm also at the age where I need to start planning what to do with my life and how to make money and shit but I just disappoint everyone who wants things from me because I can't stay motivated because I just don't have a PURPOSE. I just wish I had something I could be proud of and that I could be respected or respect myself for, something I poured all this energy I have inside me into, something that I can die with satisfaction knowing that I did. I don't even know what kind of advice you could give me lol, but honestly if you have any thoughts or anything at all it would be really cool :)
093718.answer: wait, that's not true. One of the coolest things about our universe is the way things can change yes, this is good. you are getting charged up. You will probably experience some high passions and maybe a lot of envy and jealous rage, at this time. jealous of the people whose content you are consuming, because you really would like to be the one creating the content. At least that has been my experience that's every age with the amount of passion you have already demonstrated, you are going to find this in copious quantities, throughout your life. When in this moment it may seem like these 'purposes' are in 0 places, pretty soon you will find them in infinite places. infinity has a weird tendency to look like 0 sometimes. i think the first step is to be aware of this fact (at least it was for me). which is to realize that massive possibilities and potential exists literally everywhere, in everything. For me, i've dedicated my life to proving this, but before i felt like i had done it, i was always searching for any time i felt like someone else had proved it, and latch onto that and study it and use it as proof that it can be done. I feel i should probably stop telling everyone to "write" a lot, because maybe some people just don't enjoy witing. But .... for you, it seems like you are perfectly comfartable writing, as you've just demonstrated. So i think you should find your most comfortable writing tool (a text editor on a computer, wherever you are most comfortable writing/typing), and just start.... USING it. Do anything you can in it. Use it to be honest. Use it to paint pictures. i don't care what you use it for, .... anywhere between honesty and art, fiction to diagrams, .... i mean, just test the keyboard, to start out with. Make sure every key is working. This will be one of the simplest ways to get your brain to start putting things into the world. Basically what we need to do is open up these pathways so your brain can start communicating with the world and putting things out there. you've demonstrated clearly that you are in the sort of 'consuming' stage, with some pent up desire to be the one on the other end of that. Maybe watch some film directors interviews on youtube. That could be a starting place. You might not want to direct films, but it might remind you of something else you do want to do. But another thing i should remind you, finding these things is like a river. You just make your best guess and do a thing, and then along the way you will hear some signals that will give you another hint of what you should try next. Trust me, these rivers ALWAYS get to huge dank oceans, eventually, if you let them flow. And you have made it clear that you have a huge amount of water to start with

093726.question: how did you highlight the globe for hotewig? on a 2d map, you mask the section and change the hue. in order to project the map onto the globe, do you need to do a UV mapping?
093726.answer: the best way i found, was to export 2 versions of the same 3D clip. First you have to make an alternate map. Take the world map you're using (probably an equirectangular, 1 by 2 rectangle), and make a second map, with everything blacked out except your desired region. Then, swap in that map to the globe, then re-render the exact same clip, with the exact same camera movement, in the exact same time range. Then, when you import those clips to your 2D program, put the region/black map on top. then key out the black. then fuck the colors as desired

093801.question: hey bill, I really like your videos and they really help me lift my mood up after a bad day. I am still figuring out my life since I'm quite young and I'm not exactly sure what my talents are. Seeing you make videos in your own style inspires me a lot. If you don't mind, could you give me some advice on how to figure out what I'm good at? Also when did you realise that making songs and videos was your thing? I'm not sure if you'll see this but I just wanted to thank you :)
093801.answer: you just have to start doing some different things after many years of being mostly a drummer (and partially a keyboard player), but just wanting MORE, and then gradually trying to figure out what i want to put in songs, spent many many years doing that, then spent many more years writing a lot of songs, then spent many more years trying to figure out how to actually record all the parts myself in a way that i felt would be good enough, then finally i realized i still wanted MORE so i tried to figure out how to make videos. Then i made videos for several years then decided i still wanted much much more, so i tried to revolutionize the video making, and i'm still kind of trying to do that, but i also still want MORE videos, so that means i have to sort of revolutionize things in a slightly different way, and still in addition to all of that i still want MORE types of videos that i haven't made yet but i've written some of them. As you can see i'm a fairly greedy person

093872.question: I often find myself inventing rhythm, beats and formulating whole songs I can hear in my head, then forgetting them due to a lack of musical theory knowledge or instrument to play to get them out. 093934.question: What do I do when I have so much raw inspiration and so little inspiration that's concentrated into actual tangible ideas?
093934.answer: start with a very simple and easy format. just writing on paper. or maybe typing text, if you prefer. or maybe just drawing with a pencil. Something that's easy for you and where you'll get instant results. and just start using it, in any way. just start doing anything with it. we're going to want to eventually open up many doors so that your inspirations can be delivered to the world. there are many different ways to do this, some are complicated, some or more simple, and you can learn them over time. but, the only place to start really is something very simple that you can get instant results. Maybe the result you get will simply be knowledge of the next specific step

093935.question: I think a lot about art (including yours maybe even especially yours) and I try really hard to interpret things and it often makes me feel very bad because I feel like I am failing to get the meaning out of something. I feel very stupid like the conclusions I am coming to are baseless and/or wrong and bad or maybe I'm not even coming to any real conclusions at all. do you have any thoughts on these feelings? is it possible I am just thinking too much and being ridiculous or am I really just wrong about everything. sometimes I can listen to a song of yours and it speaks to me in these very difficult to explain and powerful ways but other times I might listen to the same song and feel like I can't even begin to wrap my head around the smallest concepts.
093935.answer: if you enjoy it, or if it made you feel something, or if it meant something to you, then it might be worth thinking about. i'm sure you'll come up with something. and if you didn't feel anything, that's ok, it was a failure to communicate somewhere, no need to blame yourself, the customer is always right.
