093938.question: when did you start making "I'm a princess"
093938.answer: i wrote the song starting on march 20, 2019, the song recording was finished by april 27, 2019, then i immediately started on the video, then i got lost in the wonderful world of 3D graphics........ forever ...... then, starting around june/july 2019, i started moving to an entirely new computer system because i was long overdue to do that. then that opened a few dozen hundred cans of worms. then just when i thought i had fallen too far into the abyss to ever save myself, i snapped out of it and demanded that i simply just do "a video" any way i can. but 'princess' didn't feel like a good first one. so i did a different one. then immediately after that one was done (january 16, 2021) i assembled the pieces from 'princess' and continued working on it

094071.question: hi bill. when making music, making ideas and stuff comes easy but when I try to revise them I just never get it done. my teacher and my parents push me to revise my works, but it's hard to find motivation. any thoughts? (btw you're amazing)
094071.answer: the risk in 'revising' is that it might make it worse and less genuine. The benefit, however, is that it might make it more coherent. I spent a long time being unable or afraid to do this. i just kept writing new things. but eventually i just got so jealous of 'normal' songs, for having a repeating chorus, etc, that i figured it out. Half of the struggle, i think, is just choosing which item you're going to work on. for me it was necessary to first gather all the items into a list. Then i would go through the list one at a time, and make a few moves on each one. the 'diagnosis' is important. Play through the existing material, get a first impression, see if you generally like it or if it sucks, .... then start diagnosing it. If it's a small idea, figure out if it's the beginning or not the beginning. If it's already a long / complete idea, just go through from the beginning and find the first place where it truly sucks or is not good enough. This point is what i call the 'split point', the point where the existing material stops being good enough. So you put the rest aside, and write from there. I generally don't think it's good to plan on writing to connect to what comes after -- very risky and strange to do this. But it might happen automatically. so you can be open to that, but, plan on just writing from the split point and doing what's truly right from the split point

And from years of asking around, i've pretty much figured out that the only way to do that is if you've been granted an SRAV contract, which is something that pretty much only record labels get to have. So i need to either sign away a percentage of my music revenue to a company, OR continue to climb the ranks of society just a little bit more. it's cool, i just got some fresh ladders

What's going on in your brain? you're just thinking about what you're talking about. You are not thinking about the words. How the heck does this happen? from what i understand, this is one of the miracles of the Language part of the brain. its power is overhwelming to me, especially when i think of all the words i don't know i know

094337.question: what were you trying to do with the chords in the bridge (the "road doesn't end" part) of long long long journey? specifically the fact that they're over an arpeggio of a different chord. (i'll totally accept "i just wrote random chords and it sounded good" as an answer btw)
094337.answer: do the bridge random chords usually don't work. what seems to be happening in the bridge of long long journey is quite a common phenomenon. if the song is in F#, imagine we've jumped to the key of A except we're never using the 1 (A) chord. this happens all the time in these sorts of sections. Also it's not an arpeggio. it doesn't repeat

094338.question: you're really cool and you make really neat music and that's not a question so i'll ask: how do you come up with the chord progressions for your songs? is it some super structured and complicated process or are you just having fun and screwing around?

094343.question: i'm really upset because i feel like there's no point to me putting all these emotions on the internet through music to get zero views. i know that's very irrational and probably raises many questions like "am i sure i want to do this" and "am i doing this for other people rather than for myself". these questions have obvious answers to my conscious mind (yes i want to do this and no i'm not doing this for other people), but i wonder if another answer is lurking subconsciously. i'm trying to decide if i should take a break and find my intentions or maybe even find another outlet for my feelings. what do you think?
094343.answer: first, just sit yourself down (or stand up) and ask yourself if you truly want the views. If the answer is yes, (it certainly was for me), there is a 2-part strategy i can recommend. first, keep doing the content, regularly and ruthlessly, to the absolute greatest of your ability. then, (or at the same time), open up some social media accounts in your artist name and begin GENTLY but ruthlessly interacting with many many many people, in the most honest and genuine way you can. i should clarify that this strategy is tailored toward the person who's answer to the first question was a resounding 'yes', mostly because it takes a long long time to do it effectively. but it does work

Imagine if the release of your large catalog was held up by the creation of videos. The songs mean so much more to me.

094401.question: what sort of instrument do you use to fill in the chords in songs? The chords usually seem full and chordy but i can't hear what instrument is playing them. Is it some synth?
094401.answer: sometimes you can get magical results by combining 2 different ones. sometimes the results are even more magical if you sort of only play half the chord with one of the instruments. The trick is to just pick an instrument you have, then, go through the entire song and very carefully and inquisitively just sort of test the waters to see where you can get a word (note) in. i call this the sprinkle method, which has its advantages and disadvantages, but, the advantage is that sometimes the natural blending effect makes it sound like you have more magical instruments than you really have

094408.question: I want to try writing out the entirety of my songs before I start making them in a DAW, but I don't know how to read or write sheet music, do you have any advice?
094408.answer: yes. make small demos. what works best for me is i use a lyric sheet with references to the audio demo. so it looks like tempo= 92 see recording 771 for timed run through recoring 770 for more detailed demo / talk thru lyric lyric lyric lyric lyric lyric lyric lyric lyric lyric (recording 557) lyric lyric lyric lyric (recording 559) and the recordings will be just a live vocal+keyboard demo and also explaining any other necessary details or instructions i might have. Usually i will also let the recordings run while i am trying to come up with the ideas, just to make sure i catch anything i come up with. then when i think i'm sure, then i'll jump to the next recording and demo it concisely and that will be the recording that is referenced in the lyric sheet. then of course when it's all done, do a timed run through on a click, where you might miss a couple of lyrics but the important thing is to see the proper road map, then, you can also have a more detailed one, where you may stop and clarify whatever you need

094489.question: When i play piano both of my hands want to do the same thing. How do i fix this?
094489.answer: first figure out what you want them to do. there are some key questions to ask first: are you playing by yourself? who has the melody? (your voice, your hand, someone else's voice or hand, etc). Who is playing bass? (your left hand, someone else,)... Who is playing the chords? (you, someone else)... The answer to these questions will determine what each of your hands should be doing. and then there are different strategies depending on how many jobs you have to do. In some cases, maybe your hands only have 1 job, in which case it's not a bad idea to put 1 hand behind your back

094566.question: How do I get past the feeling that I'll never make a piece of music that's as beautiful or emotionally moving as my favorite artists' works? I'm studying multiple artists' works like crazy, listening to what sounds, rhythms, and melodies work best, but I feel like everything I make would be a stripped-down parody devoid of any authentic meaning.
094566.answer: here's the one thing to realize about music (or art) which might make this whole puzzle start to make sense. it's a magic trick. it's a miracle. it's weird and strange, and the more the scientists try to figure out what the "right" answer is, the damn music will change again and find a new way to knock your socks off even more. So, knowing the paradoxical and mischievous nature of this, it's probably time to start looking at the other side of the coin here, and instead of trying to find something that's actually "right", try doing something "wrong" on purpose. you might be surprised by the results

094613.question: Most categories on this website lead to a page called billwurtz.com/(category name).html or some variation on it like dropping the .html. For some reason, the "scarmble" category leads to a page called billwurtz.com/anagrams/anagrams.html instead of billwurtz.com/scarmble/scarmble.html, why?
094613.answer: anagrams is what it actually is. but a lot of people don't know what 'anagram' means (a lot of people actually think it means acronym). so instead i've labeled it "scramble" except i've scrambled the letters slightly for 2 reasons: because it matches the style of many of the other categories, and also because it is relevant to that category itself. Also it's important to notice that none of the scrambled titles are ever scrambled when they appear in the URL. this is a decoration scheme which relies on the colors, and would not be done without the colors

094804.question: I feel like our community bitching has turned into both an assignment & a crucible for you. A crucible that only makes production gods. You now exist in a league all your own. That said, watch out for him heidecker he's the anti-you. Actually you two should start a beef on his podcast. 094857.question: the more time i spend on working on a musical idea, the less excited i am about it. but i also feel that if i didn't spend much time on it, it would be bad. Eventually, i always end up not getting anywhere and i give up on my compositions. Any advice?
094857.answer: save them in a list. so even if you have to stop working on it, you're still not giving up on it. music is like weird magic voodoo that only seems to work when you are not trying and not paying attention. so just keep the ideas listed where they belong, and then as long as you've familiarized yourself with them, you'll probably come up with the answers without even trying, some other time when you least expect it. If you feel like you must finish it, you can also do that but you just need to be very patient and calm and sit with it, and don't be alarmed if you are too tense to get anything for several hours. if you are patient, it will come, i'm sure. it literally can't stay away forever. science tells us this

094892.answer: ? did you actually not notice that that is the english alphabet backwards it's usually not going to be cryptography. i will give you an example of a small thing that may or may not be hidden (depending on whather you've noticed it) and what it means. the boat in the "i'm a princess" video says "boath". that's because it is a boat but it also looks like a bath. is it a boat? is it a bath? or is it both? so the answer, of course, is boath

094929.question: why did you reupload "Money" on Spotify?

094930.question: I had a dream I wrote a piece of music, and I heard the music, but I don't remember it anymore now that I'm awake, and I'm just left feeling weird and kinda sad that dream me is better at music-ing than real me. How do you remember the music in your dreams? Do you always? Or do I just have to move on and hope to come across a new song while conscious?
094930.answer: that's understandable. being awake can be quite a hinderance to writing write it down and/or sing it and describe it into a recording as fast as you can sometimes i can't catch it all you should do that too, because dream ideas can be rare. What you can do, when working while you're awake, is just be patient, and know that sometimes nothing happens for a long time until you can finally get truly comfortable. in a way, it only works if you stop wanting it to work. And this can be quite difficult, especially if you want the music as much as i do. but if you're patient, it HAS to happen eventually. science tells us this

094984.question: I'm not sure what you meant by "when did all the windmills start to turn so slow". Maybe it's supposed to be literal, idk. That line has stuck with me a lot, probably more than 99% of lyrics I've ever listened to. A very weird sense of a nostalgia for a moment I've never experienced. Have they rusted and fallen into decay? Could be that it's just a feeling of looking away and then back and recognizing that you never paid attention to the things right in front of you, because otherwise you'd know the speed. Or maybe the speed hasn't changed, but in youth everything looks bigger, faster, more vibrant and full of life and character. I'm def rambling at this point, and maybe getting a definitive answer will ruin the magic for me, idk. But thank you from the bottom of my heart for this song, I'll never forget it.

094986.question: At the beginning of your most recent song, "got some money", when you say "and I wonder if I'm sad about the money that I have, what is the music there. Is there any name for it. Where it gets lower and lower and with the little bit at the end. I also have a similar question for the line "and it makes me mad", which is about 35 seconds in. Same thing, what is the term for the music happening there. With emphasis on 'me mad'. That's all.
094986.answer: the best names i have for it is just the names of all the notes and chords. the notes are E, D#, C#, C in the melody. then i think you probably want to put the bass with it on the same notes, for beef, except on "have", i am definitely using a chord known as G#dominant7, and the important part of that chord in this case will be: you want the C note (melody) then you also want the F# note with that, somewhere in the harmony, and then you'd have G# in the bass. And i can't remember if i put the bass in G# (root of the chord) or C (with the melody), let me listen and check. ok yes the bass is on G#. Also i've harmonized the melody a 3rd above, so "money that i" will also have notes G#, F#, E, and then it seems for "have", instead of harmonizing a 3rd above, for that one i've used F# as the harmony note, as i said, to get the best results on that chord you need the F# and C notes to give it that twang. with the G# in the bass. again, i can just tell you the notes. there's hardly any chords in here, except "mad". the bass is just wandering toward the important note (the "mad" chord), and the chord for mad could be pretty much described as D7 (D dominant7), and in this case, to get the sound you want there, really all you want is the note F# (in the melody), you want C also in the harmony, and you want D in the bass. that should do the trick

095005.question: Any tips for learning bass?
095005.answer: throw yourself into a professional working band as soon as possible. But, in case it is a disease year, here's something else i can recommend: take your favorite songs, and delete the bass. This is pretty easy to do if you have a phone, tablet, or laptop. just play it without any headphones, and it automatically deletes the bass. then, make sure your bass IS plugged into something that is large so you can actually hear it (like an amp) and play along. Generally what i'm trying to say, get yourself into a situation where you are actually playing the bass role in songs, as soon as possible. that's pretty much where you are going to learn everything. Start out by just playing the root note of each chord (for example, if the chord is C, play the C note). Try to hold back from doing anything else just yet. but then pretty soon, as if by magic, you're automatically going to start doing everything you need to do and have a wild time

095116.question: how do you prime factor 1021
095116.answer: see if the digits add up to 3, which they don't, then check for 7, so ditch the 21 and see if the 10 is a multiple of 7 which it's not, then check for 11 by subtracting it from 1021 which makes 101 (after you drop the zero at the end) and check if 101 is a multiple of 11 which you should know it's not because 101 is prime, then check for 13 by adding 39 to 1021 which makes 106 (after you drop the zero at the end) then divide by 2 to get 53 and check if that's a multiple of 13 which of course it's not because it's neighbor 52 already is, then check 17 by eliminating the 102 from the left of 1021 and you're left with 1 which is not a multiple of 17, then check 19 by adding it to 1021 and you get 104 (after dropping the zero at the end) and you probably already know 104 is not a multiple of 19 (divide it by 2 a few times and you'll just get to 13), then check 23 by adding 69 to 1021 to get 109 (after you drop the zero) which is prime so 23 is out, then check 29 by adding it to 1021 which makes 105 (after you drop the zero) which you might already know as just 7x15 so no 29s there, then you can check 31 by subtracting it from 1021 which makes 99 (after you drop the zero) and we all know that 99 is just 11x9 (without any 31s in it), then you can check 37 except i THINK we're already done because i think 37 squared is already higher than 1021 because 32 squared is 1024 (famously) so 37 squared can't be any lower than that. and if 37 squared is higher than 1021, then that means we're never gonna find any other prime factors higher than that, because, if we did, their partner factor would have to be something lower and we checked everything lower already, so 1021 is prime, so your answer is an earth shattering 1x1021

095221.question: when you said you could see that 262147 didn't have a 7 in its factorization, how did you know that? since there is no easy rule for divisibility by 7
095221.answer: you can legally knock off the 7 from the right side. and it still will or won't be divisible by 7. do you see what i mean? so, imagine if you could make legal moves like this, until eventually you got it down to something you could recognize. So you can knock the 7 off. then you still have a 14 on the end. so obviously you can subtract 14 and you'll still be left with the same status of 7-ness (or non.) Then you're left with 262, and of course you can divide it all you want and that won't change the 7-ness either. so go ahead and divide it by 2, which is super easy, digitally. just halve the digits and it's 131. Ok so i already know that one is prime just because i know my primes up to at least there. but if you didn't know 131, you can of course subtract 21 (again, that won't change the 7-ness of the main number). so that brings you to 110 and you can drop the zero (again, dividing (by 10) won't change its 7-ness). so you drop the zero and it's 11, and please tell me you can tell by looking at it if 11 is divisible by 7 (it's not). so the original number couldn't have been, because we've only made legal moves up to here

095227.answer: you'll get this, in time. you just have to listen to a lot of music. you'll get it when you least expect it. how about this, have you ever tried working in a store where they play a broad and well established popular repertoire through the ceiling

095228.question: Why did you decide to stop working on i'm a princess at one point and start here comes the sun?
095228.answer: i did a heck of a lot in between. i stopped working on i'm a princess because the world of 3D was so vast and overwhelming and i was so in love with it, i needed to get as deep as i could into it, which also requires some significant renovations, and i also got really into those too. Then finally when i had hit rock bottom and needed to pretty much 'make a video or die', i think i decided i wanted to start fresh, with something a little more straightforward. although in retrospect, 'princess' would have been pretty good there. but the other technical reason is because the video was already like 20% made in the old system, and i was certainly in no mood to go back to the old system, and yet i still desperately wanted to use the footage, because it was very sentimental to me, because it literally shows the moment where i fell in love with 3D. So i knew it was going to be somewhat of an odd case, a frankenstein project, that would have to be pieced together cleverly to combine old and new. a bit too complicated of an endeavor for me to attempt in the first go. in addition it obviously required character animation, for continuity purposes, which actually i was quite ready for because i developed most of that in early 2020. but i still wasn't ready for it yet. i tried a cameo in the 'sun' song to prepare

095268.question: im confused about note/note chords. would c/e be e c e g (normal c chord with an extra e below it)or e g c (flipped version of c chord)?
095268.answer: i would say if your chart says C/E, that means the E note is probably supposed to be a bass note. (so, probably at least an octave away from the rest of the chord. As for whether you think it's necessary to still include another E note in the midrange part of the chord, that's up to you. it can be nice to put the E in the bass and actually just play C and G in the midrange of the chord. that's a pretty nice sound that is found readily all over all types of music you've heard. you'll have to check to see which seems to sound better at that point in the song you're playing, and on the instrument you're using. If the arranger has a specific preference, then they're gonna have to tell you directly or else write out the notes in the chart

095299.question: Oh hi thanks for checking in I'm still a piece of garbage How was that comes to your mind
095299.answer: i was doing a writing exercise where i was writing jingle videos based on old notebook entries. I would randomize a date, then look up what i had was writing or thinking about on that date. Then i would try my best to summarize musically what was happening. So i got one from the summer of 2007, i looked at the page from then, and it was really bad. very uninspired, useless in almost every way. i could tell i was feeling quite worthless on that day. I the jingle i made was "hello, i'm a piece of garbage" (not the one you are referring to), which seemed appropriate. Then, maybe a couple of selections later, just by chance, i got one from the next day immediately after that (also in the summer of 2007). And it had exactly the same sort of affliction. So i really wasn't sure what to do, because it seemed like i had already done this one. But, so often, honesty is the best answer to things, so i framed the jingle as a sequel to the previous one, doing essentially the same thing

095322.question: what do you call that chord when, say in the key of C, you have F in the bass and in the melody you have B (and G) resolving to A (and F)? Can you ever call that Fsus2add#11 (or #4?), also what if the 5 isn't included (is it included usually?), thabks (it's like a double suspension methinks)
095322.answer: Fsus2b5 is the most efficient way i can think of. If you are in a world where F2 is understood to mean Fsus2, then, F2b5 is definitely the way to go. If i were writing it on a chart for myself personally, i would say F2#4, and i know maybe that means 5 is allowed when it's not there, but, seeing that i would probably get that i'm supposed to focus on the 2 and #4. And also, if the next chord is F, then i think as a reader i'd easily pick up on the movement that's implied. As you can see, charts can be a lot of approximation and guessing games. Now that i think about it, writing words and sentences is like that too sometimes

095365.answer: i'm surprised you are ok with the longer stuff but not the shorter stuff. i would think shorter stuff would be a starting point if you can't do long stuff yet no yes, that's it the only theories that i consider valid are the ones that are based on the way the notes actually sound. although this may be an unpopular opinion you just have to magically think of them, just the same way you can magically think of the words you use when you talk. i don't know exactly how we do that, but i know that you get better the more you familiarize yourself with the playing field. so, for language, we just spend a lot of years in the world listening to people talk and trying to do it ourselves. for music, you can spend a lot of years listening to music and playing around with your favorite instruments. Also, because songwriting involves language, it can be helpful to spend a lot of time free-writing

095370.question: So how come you made the chorus for "la de da de da de da de day oh" in 2010, but the rest of the song way later? Did you just read through your old notes and went "this is pretty darn good, I can use this"? And did you do the same for here comes the sun?
095370.answer: i did not, that part was made in 2012. the verse before it was made in 2010 it's like a much much more meticulous and complicated version of that. i can write much faster than i can produce, so from 2008 to 2012 there was sort of a writing epidemic going on, where i just kept writing and writing and writing. not necessarily even finishing them. so in september 2012 i started gathering a chronological list of every song or partial song i had ever written, and then i started working little bits on each one. the same list continues to this day. So when it's time to record/produce and song/video, i have an elaborate writing/selection process where i write some brand new things first, add them to the list, then go through the entire list, pick out good candidates for the next production (i usually end up choosing about 25), then i do some additional writing on some of those, then finally i make my final selection. Then i continue writing that one to completion. The idea of casually finding a song, and just thinking 'oh this is good so i'll do it' seems hilarious to me. that's just not how it works. my mind has to go to full scale war with itself to settle on a song selection

095380.question: epic songs, epic melody, but why do you make some part of the lyrics dont rhyme, i mean, you said have instead of had in the money video
095380.answer: i think rhyming the entire word all the way up to every last consonant sound usually sounds pretty bad, and tends to feel empty. it seems to feel much much more meaningful to me when only the vowel sound is the same, and the rest of the word sounds different. and in some cases i am open to using a completely different sounding word because sometimes i think that sounds the best and has the most meaningful impact. If the words rhyme too well then i think as a listener i would get the sense that the writer doesn't even care what the words mean. But if the word sounds slightly different the next time around, then you get a nice feeling of growth and change

095404.question: trying to analyze the rhythmic phrasing of the wild fill in 'i'm a princess' (at 2:38) 1. is the first little run a 16th triplet / 24th note thing or something like a nested qaudruplet in the space of 3 16th notes plus an additional note on the 2? 2. the last triplety sounding thing isn't really a triplet is it? what's that about? help, i am a dunce!
095404.answer: it's this imagine you took 3 8th note triplets, starting on beat 3 and then an additional downbeat on beat 4. (so 4 notes in total). now displace all of that forward in time by an eighth note. so to notate it you'd probably have to break it down into 16th note triplets with 16th note triplet spaces in between, so you can start it on the '&' of 3 and end it on the '&' of 4

095440.question: Any tips for transcribing drum parts of songs?
095440.answer: get a solid understanding of time. beats per bar, ticks per beat. i can recommend this popular counting system: "1, 2, 3, 4" "1 & 2 & 3 & 4 &" "1e&a2e&a3e&a4e&a" then you can use that as like an address system. then you'll be able to hear any note in time and understand whether it's on the "& of 4", or maybe the "a of 2", or perhaps the "e of 3"

095469.question: Hey bill. So I've read a lot of other questions about writing melodies/lyrics at the same time. I have applied it and got some nice verse melodies with lyrics I like too. But now I'm in a predicament with the second verse. Now I'm kind of back to trying to puzzle piece lyrics into the preexisting verse melody. I've tried to come up with a new melody/lyrics but then it seems too unrelated to the beginning. So what's the technique for getting around this/ what do you do to help with writing second verses are things like them? Thank so much!!
095469.answer: anything can happen, but the only way you're gonna get the answers is if you can trick your brain to stop worrying about it. which gets more and more difficult the more you care. which, if you're like me, is a lot. Also the time when you're gonna get the right answer is gonna be after you've heard the whole thing through from the beginning up to the stopping point, in real time. what i would recommend is, record a run-through of what you have, then play some sort of calming sound-free game whilst listening to the recording. and don't be alarmed if you don't seem to get ANYTHING. you'll just have to wait a little longer until your brain actually calms down and until you actually are not thinking about it. then, plentiful answers will flow like water. then the race is on to catch them all in time

095476.question: how do you prime factor numbers so well? you're great at doing it
095476.answer: you have to check to see if each smaller prime number goes into it. to do that, you can modify the big number by small multiples of the small number, until you get it to something you recognize. most of the trick is to get the big number to even out to a multiple of 10, then you can drop the zeros and it still maintains its same status of whether or not it is divisible by the smaller prime number you're checking into it

095490.question: there are so many problems going on in the world: the environment, poverty, governmental issues. i believe that i would have the ability to dedicate myself to one of these and do my part in some way by studying applied science, economics, or politics, but at this point in my life i find myself much more focused on artistic pursuits in music and mathematics. i know artists are important to society, but i can't help but often think that my work would be better spent trying to solve those more dumpster-fire-like issues i mentioned. i know you are currently and have been for a while very fully focused on your artistic pursuits, and i admire that a lot and would enjoy being in such a position as well. but part of me feels like it's unfair for me to just dance on the sidelines while everyone else is in the middle of all the real problems. has this ever been a concern for you?
095490.answer: (i hope you don't forget about the good things in the world also) you have a lot of mindfulness about this, which is cool, although don't let it distract you from doing the great work that you can do. Another way to think of it, here are some examples of other problems which many people in the world may face: sadness, misery, hopelessness, confusion, etc... Many of those problems might find their strongest remedy in art and music. and many people have no idea how to go about doing that. So your role as an artist/musician might be even more valuable than you realize

095492.question: do you think the louder you get a mix, the tighter the volume levels have to be for its elements? sometimes i want to just put a "maximizer" on my master and realize as soon as i start pumping everything, the unbalances become more noticeable, the loud start feeling louder in comparison to the mix etc. im not sure if its the maximizer, just the volume perception, or what.
095492.answer: i am guessing it's not working properly. if it's doing what it's supposed to, it should even out the volume. it might be just making everything louder, because the settings might not be right for your mix and you might just be hearing the 'make up gain' by default, which would just make it louder and not do anything. (this is what happened to me in the early stages). what i would suggest is to make sure there is no make up gain, then make sure the ratio is not 1:1 (make sure the first number is higher), then raise the threshold all the way up. Now it should be doing exactly nothing. then press the bypass button on and off to compare, and it should sound exactly the same. Also check to see if there is a 'reduction' monitor so you can see when it's actually doing something. So now it should be doing nothing. Now, with the bypass off (so the compressor is ON), start gradually lowering the threshold until you start to see the 'reduction' meter gradually start to light up when it hits those loud parts, and it should be tapering them down. then once you've compressed it down a little then you can raise the make up gain

095509.question: How do I get better at identifying chords by ear (I, IV, V, etc.)
095509.answer: one small thing i could suggest is to stop using roman numerals, because they're just numbers anyway, and those all look too much the same when they keep combining the same 2 letters together. But if that's what you're used to, then that's ok. i'm just guessing that our arabic numberals (1,2,3,4 etc) might be more familiar to you (they certainly are for me). in any case, i would say you should just start going through all the songs you know and working out the chords for them, in any way you can (besides looking them up on the internet, only because that will probably get you the wrong chords), and then over time you will get really really good at it, and start to notice some patterns, then you will see all those patterns break, then if you can keep your head together you will probably start to notice patterns in how the patterns break, then of course you will see those patterns break as well, and then, somewhere around here, it's your turn

095543.question: So I think about things all the time but I never write them cause as soon as I start writing them, they feel stupid and meaningless. 095543.answer: there is meaning laced through every fiber of our world. but it has to seemingly be balanced with non-meaning. i've learned it's best not to fight with this natural up and down flow. But if you're wondering how to get this to happen while you are actually equipped with writing tools, my suggestion for that is just gradually start using the writing tools more and more, without worrying about whether anything is 'good' yet. then one day, when you least expect it, the unpredictable flow of meaning will continue as it always does, except the tools will already be comfortable in your hands

095558.question: how do you find/make all of the cool instruments in your music? i have a hard time finding good instruments to use.
095558.answer: here's a good trick i use: shorten the release and the attack. most sounds you will find, to start off, are a total mess, with a really long attack and release. probably meant for someone who doesn't really play the keyboard that much and just wants to achieve success by holding down 1 note. But when i shorten up the attack and release, then that very quickly turns it into something that is delightful for me to play, as a keyboard player. Another thing you can do is program in something on one of the wheel controls. my 2 favorite options for this are filter cutoff (wawawawaw), and vibrato. To do a nice vibrato the way i like, set the LFO to somewhere around 4x per second, then make the LFO control the pitch up and down, then, set the wheel to increase the depth of the LFO as you push the wheel up. If you have things on the wheels then i think you're gonna have a lot of fun and be able to express yourself really well

095566.question: When I'm in the middle of completing a hard portion of a goal, I often have a strong urge in the middle of hardship or annoyance to run away from the task and do something pleasant. It hits repeatedly, and accompanies a virtual titanium wall that starts to prevent me from moving forward and even if I can stand to get past it I work very slowly. If I cant stand it, I abandon the process. How can I better deal with or eliminate this pernicious feeling?
095566.answer: i think it's time to have a discussion about it. first, harken back to when the project was first started, and recall what it's really all about, and why you are doing it. this often helps. And the other thing you can do is discuss the specific procedure. If you are hitting a wall, it often means that you don't actually know exactly what you are supposed to do next. sometimes you think you know, but you don't actually know, and this can be a reason for things being slow. discussing things usually helps a lot

095626.question: How do you learn to figure out what different chords are by ear?
095626.answer: go through about 50 of your favorite songs, and identify each chord with brute force. quickly unpause/pause (or nowadays you can edit to loop a tiny fraction of audio very quickly) and just pick it out note by note and put it together. write down all the chords to a song (in time, with bar lines, etc.)..... once you do this for about 30 or 40 songs, i think you will find that you don't have to search for the individual notes anymore. ... maybe not even pause it at all. After about 100 more songs, you probably won't even have to listen to the song, you will be able to do it from memory. after about 1000 songs, you will probably be able to hear someone singing the melody for a song you have never heard before, without hearing the chords, and figure out what the chords should be. after 10,000 songs, you should be able to play chords along with them on the first try, never having heard the song before, and have them think you already knew the song

095641.question: You're a huge inspiration to me and I'm very interested in your songwriting process, I hope you don't mind a handful of questions. 095660.question: can you explain what the chords are for the song I like? I think it's really catchy and I would like to learn the song, but I can't figure out the chords. Thanks!
095660.answer: i have good news and bad news. The good news is, i have the original chart of when i wrote it, all on paper, years before i ever recorded it. The bad news is, it's not guaranteed to be entirely accurate because when i record a song, i am potentially allowed to invoke the 'suck' clause and change some of the details IF i thought it sucked. but the good news is, i'm looking at the chart right now and it seems extremely accurate. the bad news is that the end was re-written (not shown on this chart) but the good news is that the new ending is only 4 bars, in replacement of 27 bars on the chart, and those new 4 bars, if they were written in this chart language, would not have shown any chords, it would be notated as rap only, in a similar notation language to the 27 bar ending you do see. so you wouldn't have seen any chords from the chart there anyway. The bad news of course, is that for sections like that, in this chart language, you never see any chords, and chordal decisions for those types of sections are made during the recording. However the good news is that the only other part like this would be the intro, and i think i actually did not use any chords there in the recording either. However the bad news is, for that new 4 bar section which occurs in the recording but not the chart, there IS chordal information there (arranged when recording) that would certainly NOT be reflected in the chart. Also the other bad news is that the final recording is not guaranteed to be done in the same key as the chart, BUT the good news is, in this case it actually was. The good news is, i'm pretty sure i must have some sort of document somewhere that indicates the writing of those last 4 bars, either a written update or a recorded writing demo, but the bad news is i can't seem to find it and now i think it doesn't exist, and it seems more likely that i was feeling brave enough to actually re-write a 4 bar ending on the spot, in the recording session, which is a rare occurence but not impossible. The good news is i just found the written update which contains the last line written at the end. and i can say for certain that you are supposed to cross out the entire line before "v2" and also cross out everything up until that new line. the only reason i probably didn't cross it out is because i knew i was already recording it so i didn't need to make note of that change. but i can assure you that i never intended for that additional 4 bars to be in addition to the other 27. they are intended to replace everything from "get it" and after. so with some assembly required, you can take the original page 1 from here, then cross out the last 27 bars and REPLACE it with the last 4 bars of this page. and the extra 27 bars remains as a bonus alternate ending, which should NOT include the final 4

095679.question: So I've been doing that thing where I try and catch the musical ideas before they fly past and I forget them. But now what happens, is I catch maybe 4 bars and try to get them recorded, but by the time everything's recorded, the spark is gone and all I have are these four bars. Do I just need to work faster?
095679.answer: no, i think you're doing fine. it's not expected that you can get much further than 4 bars at one time. What i think is the right thing to do here is, properly file and label your item into a list, and then carry on with your life. A separate question, for several different departments at different times, is why when and how to do anything with them, and also when and how to decide which, and a whole splintering of other questions which i would be glad to help you with as well, if you are ready to examine what your goals may be

095681.question: Hey Bill, Some of my favorite artists write songs through "divine inspiration": An entire song just appears in their head, and they just write down what they hear. The stuff they come up with is so intricate, it's unbelievable that a human could come up with it. I feel like my methodical, trial-and-error approach to creating music is vastly inferior. I study my favorite songs' chord progressions, melodies, timbres, rhythms, etc., to see what makes a song "good", and I use these conclusions to aid me in my songwriting process. But I feel like the end result isn't truly original, not inspired by something "beyond this world". When I sit down to make music, I feel like I'm forcing it. It doesn't feel authentic, and it doesn't sound original. I feel like I'm just ripping off my favorite artists. Part of me thinks that I haven't studied/practiced enough to convert inspiration into originality. I've only covered a few dozen songs i n-depth. Another part of me thinks that I don't have a creative/original mind, and never will. I know that you aren't omniscient, and this isn't an easy topic. But I would be truly grateful for any advice you have for me, based on the thoughts that I'm having.
095681.answer: what makes you think they succeed at this every single time they try? that's the magic of music, and imagination in general from what you're saying, you say you catch yourself 'forcing' it. This makes me think you want it really really badly. Which makes sense. who wouldn't, after seeing what magic can be found in music. I think i have good and bad news for you. the good news is, it IS that magical, it IS other worldly, and pretty much everything about the way it functions best, makes it seem like it literally came from somewhere else. The bad news is ....... it reminds me of something you see in movies where the only way you get it is if you can actually stop thinking about it. And this is actually a problem i can sympathize with, because, if you want it so so so bad, how could you possibly stop thinking about it? but i think ultimately this IS what's going to happen. you WILL be able to calm down. whether you want to wait patiently or whether you keep kicking and screaming in desperation for a while and eventually exhaust yourself, and after all that is said and done, it WILL come. this may seem hard to believe but it wants you every bit as bad as you want it. it just really really needs you to be as open minded as possible, in order for it to feel comfortable arriving, because that's when it knows it can blow your mind the most. which, presumably, is what you've requested

095698.question: I've noticed you have lots of sheets and charts for some of the stuff you write. how important do you finding writing music down on paper to be? I have a traditional music background and a bachelors degree in music but when I'm actually doing stuff I ~like~ to do like song writing and recording little tunes I hardly ever write anything down minus the words and chords
095698.answer: if you're brave enough to believe you can remember the exact melody, then that's fine. i don't like to take any chances with that. i've watched people come up with a brand new awesome idea, and then play the same thing for me again tomorrow and the melody has changed and they don't realize it, and the original was definitely better. Because new song ideas are so new, you haven't heard them very much, so you are likely to forget exactly how it went. i am not comfortable trusting that the next time i look at it i'll remember the exact melody. so i must document it exactly. Whether this is done with notation or not, it doesn't really matter to me. it can be done with recording references, and nowadays i always use recording references, because we live in such a digital world. but for a long time i was using handwritten notation. The only times i ever do it with notation is when i have no instrument near me. i used to go to the library and put in earplugs and write songs that way. nowadays, when writing songs at the keyboard, i just make recorded references and cite them in the lyric sheet. The same goal is accomplished: to exactly document the lyric, melody, and chords

095713.question: this is a more general question about writing, not necessarily lyrics, but any form of creative piece. when you are stuck on a part, how do you get rid of or work around the writers block? i feel like anytime i really get into any personal projects that involve words, i end up stopping because of writers block and never return to it again, no matter how much i previously liked it
095713.answer: basically what you want to do is open up the project and then act so calm and natural that the project eventually forgets you are there. the writing doesn't want to happen if it feels like it's being watched. it wants to be able to blow your mind, and surprise you, which is really difficult for it to do if you're staring directly at it. but if you open up the project and act naturally next to it, EVENTUALLY the project will calm down and forget you're there, and then the whole thing starts writing itself

095721.question: hi, what happens when i makin a song but i make the melody but i forget to put words to it, but now i am at the melody and i don't know how to figure out what words to attach? did i fuck it up?
095721.answer: first, you must try to convince the song you are actually NOT trying to write it. make up a contract agreement that you and the song can sign, that says "i am NOT trying to 'write' this song, and will not make any attempts to do so!" and you and the song both sign it, and maybe you'll have some fine print located somewhere near the bottom of your left shoe or something. Then, as you sit down casually next to your melody, 'NOT' appearing to have any intention or desire to write the song, .... just begin trying phrases and sentences with the melody. don't worry about what's "good" or not yet, just start saying anything that comes to mind, with that melody. You will automatically start getting a feel for what the mechanics are (lyrically) of this melody. you'll see which kinds of words and phrases seem to always want to go in certain parts. and you'll just be internalizing the melody subconsciously, in the linguistic part of your mind. Then, put that aside, and just tell a story in your own words of what this melody is. When did you think of it? how did it make you feel? describe anything you know or feel about this melody and its origins. Sometimes you can even catch a glimpse of the exact essence of what the melody seems to be saying, even if it's the totally wrong number of words or syllables and has no physical resemblence to the shape or size of the melody. if you get this, definitely write it down. just try to PARAPHRASE (non-musically, in normal non-lyrical language) exactly what you think the melody seems to feel like it's saying. Now at this point the song will probably start to think you are trying to write it, with all the effort you've been putting in, so you will probably need an updated contract to assure everyone even more clearly that you are 'NOT' 'TRYING' to 'write' the song. then after that it's pretty much a waiting game. if you can stay calm and be patient enough for the song to forget you are trying to write it, that's when it's gonna happen

095738.question: How do you decide the tempo for your songs? Do you specifically right it down first or have a rough estimate of where you wanna be?

095779.question: why do you think so many people want your videos in 60 fps? for some videos i think it works very well, but for cameras and 3d animation it just feels wrong. i get the appeal but i feels likes i'm playing a video game or watching a soap opera. just feels weird.
095779.answer: i think what they really want, is to talk about 60fps. which is fair because it's an interesting subject what i've discovered, whether or not i was expecting this, is that higher frame rates REVEAL the exact nature of every motion and movement. so if your movements are anything less than absolutely world class deeply wonderful, the high frame rate will reveal how primitave those movements truly are. fake angular character animations will look fakely angular. Bezier-curved animations will look too obvious like a bezier curve (fake). A slightly nervous real human will appear nervous. a choreographed fight scene will appear choreographed. where as, at a lower frame rate, your imagination automatically fills in the gaps

095784.question: hi bill, do you usually record the bass first, as part of a rhythm backing track along with drums, or do you record it last so that you can play some melodic lines that compliment the rest of the song? paul mccartney said that he did the latter on all beatles albums from sgt peppers, and you can really hear how the bass sounds so much nicer when it compliments the rest of the song, because it was the last thing to be recorded. come to think of it, as a one man band, what is your preferred order of recording instruments? i know it would depend on the song, but if i had to guess i'd say you first record drums, bass and keys for a backing track, then vocals, and then the extra stuff that fills in the spaces like guitar or more keys and vocal harmonies
095784.answer: a long time ago i used to do it early, but nowadays i do it last. Actually most often on a solo project it's good to continue doing a series of temps and then go around the band and re-do each part, so everyone gets a chance to hear everyone else while they're playing (almost) first supertemp perc, then supertemp rhyth/chords, just to have something to sing over. then temp voc. then better instruments. then better vocal. and around we go

095819.question: How do you suggest I study rhythm? A lot of the melodies I try to make are rhythmically simple, repetitive, and boring
095819.answer: divide a bar into 4 beats. then divide each beat into 4 subdivisions. so you'll have 16 ticks per bar. Experiment with putting 1 note in the bar at different places. try putting it in every different place and sing it with a metronome and see what it sounds like. Now try putting 2 notes in the bar, in various places

095911.question: What kind and/or how much vocal training have you had?
095911.answer: never understood most vocal training, because i found breathing to be so connected to thought, i've always found it difficult to really control your breathing/air directly. so vocal triaining mostly never made sense to me in that way. so i was stuck on my own, and yet i sounded terrible. so that left me to figure out what to do. i quickly realized that there is a phenomenon at play here which is very similar to acting. you have to convince your inner-most mind to actually believe in the things you are communicating. A neat hack i found was to improvise the lyrics. i always seemed to sound much better when the words were genuinely made up at the time i'm singing them, instead of scripted. and if they are scripted, you have to ask a lot of similar questions that an actor would ask, about your character and your situation that you are trying to envoke. but aside from that, i also found out later that simply the more time singing makes you better. then much later on, a voice doctor told me that clearing your throat is bad, so i stopped doing that, and i also picked up a boring warm up exercise which i do on morning walks

095977.question: Looking at your songs list, it seems to me that you're free to do whatever you want to is the absolute milestone in your work. It marks the end of your early amateur efforts and blasts into utter professionalism. It sounds like any of your 2018 songs. How did this giant leap forward happen?
095977.answer: what you might be hearing, in the recording, is more of a willingness to pursue complete vocal harmonies. Typically what happened previously, when doing a full length song, is, by the time i get the regular vocal all done and set, i have no energy left to actually deal with all the vocal harmonies. Because it is a lot of work to do vocal harmonies. but around 2015 i started recognizing the importance of following through with that, and i prioritized it much more, and developed some effecient procedures for working through this. and almost every recording since then has used a significant amount of vocal harmonies. however it should be mentioned that the writing for that song was mostly done in 2010

096076.question: I've come to the point where i think i know most chord progresion and harmony structures in existence. This also applies to melodies and rythms. I've listened to so much music in the last two years that i think i know way to much in comparison to what i knew before. This could seem like a good thing but in fact all the music now just sounds empty. During the last two years i used to get excited when i heard a key change or an original harmonic structure, i used to listen to music all day long and know i feel like i reached the bottom and there isn't much more i can learn. I know i still can but 80% of the total is gone and i no longer enjoy music the same way I did before, ever since december that hardly any song got stuck in my head which it used to be something normal in my everyday life, I was always with songs in my head. The same happens with piano improvisation. I feel like if i no longer have anything to play or listen and I'm starting to l ose interest in music in general. What should I do? I don't want to separate music from me. Have you ever felt this way? If so, what did you do?
096076.answer: the skills/learning aspect of music was fun for me, but i've always been more deeply drawn to the 'voodoo' aspect of music. there's no end to the different levels of voodoo you can learn to do with music. and having technical skills is certainly a great starting place to explore that. But, if you are more attracted to the skills/learning aspect, there are many many more fields that i think would interest you a lot. from sports, to games, computers, quantum mechanics, and beyond. someone's gonna have to invent teleportation at some point

096143.question: I understand that the best way to improve is to practice (at making music, and also other things). but did you ever feel the urge to be perfect at something right away? if you did, do you have tips on overcoming it? will I always be better at things if I dedicate more time to them?

096147.question: im best friends with my own front door activates this part of my brain i can never reach. it's amazing. it's the bent key that somehow unlocks the safe to gold and crack. specifically talking about 1:40 to the end, all the lines connect together so perfectlyHOW WAS THIS MASTERPIECE MADE. i want the full backstory. maybe some lines from the timestamp i said would do..
096147.answer: this is exactly what happened. all my life i've struggled with the reality that it takes me much much much longer than i wish it takes, to produce anything. years go by and i'm fighting to reach a reasonable pace, and never seem to succeed. well, one day i suddenly snapped, took a desperate walk outside, got angry and screamed at the sky a little (in my mind), and just said '2 weeks or die trying'. the thing is, i'm sure i've tried saying this before, but sometimes the stars align and it works. so the first part of doing any song is song selection. i go through my list of songs, which have a writing % completion of anywhere from .1% to 100%. and i have to choose one. this is normally almost impossible for me, and to do it right, i have to spend many days on it. i went through maybe 50% of the list, and it felt like none of them were really working for me at the time, and i felt a bit pressured to do it quickly (because of the 2 week challenge i was doing), and so in a snap decision, i said 'what song do i WISH i was doing', and i was able to trick myself into imagining the first line. so that was cool, felt like i was off to a roaring start, and then suddenly a day went by and i hadn't made it out of the 'box' of that melody/chord sequence. in other words, i had maybe the first 6 lines, which, as you can hear, are all within the same exact musical figure. but what scared me most was that i had spent way too long and only come up with a few seconds. and i knew this was no way to beat the 2 week challenge. so essentially i realized that i had to finish the writing in 4 hours. so basically a ruthless burst of paranoid speed had to kick in. you can probably hear the brute force, desperation, and then attempts to deal with it, in the 'bad sign' part, and 'not gonna happen' part. basically i've hurled myself off the edge, into whatever comes next, before having earthly idea what would actually come next. so in that sense i was almost improvising (in the writing). To be clear, i'm talking about the writing, which is done entirely before the recording. so i'm not saying i improvised the song during recording. i always write the song first. but during the writing process it felt a bit like improvising because i had to write it so fast. So the next few sections sort of have their ups and downs, for better or for worse, because at this point i've convinced myself that there's no turning back, i have to just run, because there's no time. And inevitably, if you are able to truly adopt this attitude, it eventually finds its feet. and that seems to happen when it lands on the outvamp, and these last 16 bars seem to be an outpouring of the exact emotions i was dealing with, in the circumstances of the 2 week challenge and all the desperation leading up to it, and how i was dealing with it

096194.question: Hi. Can you tell us the background for "Outside"? What does it mean to you, what is it about, and what inspired it?
096194.answer: started with the chorus figure. just a nice good clean hook, concise, easy to understand. that went into the list as just that much, in march 2017. this was during the late stages of the history of the entire world video production, so it felt like i hadn't done any songwriting in ages. i took a brief break to come up with some ideas. this 'oudside' hook was one of them. then it was selected several months later, probably on a semi-random selection process. then i wrote the rest, according to my standard songwriting practices and procedures going 'outside' of something. for example, if you were in column A, try going 'outside' of column A by going over to column B. it's the feeling of thinking outside the box, combined with the feeling of going outside of your house. a fulfilling/refreshing feeling going outside the main chorus/title figure (written first) was probably inspired by the feeling of being stuck on a gargantuan non-song video project for almost a year. the rest of the song, written later, would be inspired by the central chorus/figure

096212.question: What are your thoughts on improv in music? I feel like if you're improvising a solo, they'll be some really cool segments in there.. but also probably some noodling in between. What do you think is the advantage of improvising/noodling a solo as opposed to just writing/working out a melody line to play over the solo section? I feel like most musicians can probably write a melody/lead line (whatever you want to call it) that is better than something they can improvise on the spot. I think improv can definitely be a powerful writing tool, but why not improv over x amount of bars until you work out some cool parts, cut out the noodling, and just choose the best parts.. rinse and repeat until you have a cohesive 'solo' that is fully worked out and arranged? I think, even for the most talented musicians, if they're improvising an extended solo there's probably gonna be at least some moments in there that just sound kind of aimless/meandering/not very strong.
096212.answer: it's cool improvising it might be a good way to capture something extremely genuine that could work unless the splicing makes it feel fake that may be true HOWEVER, the same can also be true of the production process

096286.question: hi you may remember me as 2 hand - 2 chords guy. i dont think i ever really got to ask what i wanted to ask since i didnt really know what i was trying to ask. i know a bit more. say i have voicing db ab eb f bb do you categorize the voicing as simply "Db add9 add13" or in some way if you have to use lower 2 notes on one hand and upper 3 in other as some sort of "Ebsus2 over Db no3" how do you file in your brain 2 different voicings for the same chord? i think if i had a name for it, which maybe it shape itself is the name (but piano is hard in the sense that the name shapes change because of the 12 key pattern). what i mean is, if i happen to give it a name, it might be easier to transpose the thing than if im trying to go by muscle memory / shape. again, shape might work in guitar since the pattern is the same just shifted, but the pattern in piano is weird when transposed. unless you think about notes relationships by intervals and not visual or muscle "templates" even simpler than ebsus2 over Db no 3, i really think about it as ebsus2 over a 5th starting at Db. or weirder even to think of it as a top bb with a 4th and 5th underneath, and on other hand Db 5th. I hope this explains it better
096286.answer: i'd call it Db6/9 if you're talking that specifically about exact voicings, then a chord symbol is not going to have enough information in it. and if it did it would be too long to read. to specify exact voicings including octave data, i think you're either gonna need staff notation or an audio sample

096305.question: If you were to write something out that was, for example, in C mixo... Would you just make the key sig as C major and flat the B's whenever they come up? Or would you put the Bb on the key sig and possibly lead to some confusion as to if the song is in Fmaj instead?
096305.answer: as common as mixolydian and dorian seem to be, for the root key of songs, still key signatures tend to be immediately interpreted as ionian or aeolian. This seems kind of disappointing, but, to be fair, it is important to have an obvious way to tell someone what the real root key of a song is. Weirdly, most of the time, the key signature seems to be used to display this info AS IF it were ionian or aeolian, and then rudely use accidentals all the time. which feels kind of sad/wrong, but it happens. But actually, if you write 'C mixolydian' on the top of the page and then do it with a 1 flat key signature, i don't think anyone will mind

096409.question: in the grand scheme of things, do we really matter? will we make an impact on anything that happens? is life meaningless? if life has a meaning, what is it? does anything really matter? is life random, or does everything happen for a reason?

096520.question: In the video for "I'm a princess," there is an almost-constant border around part or all of the scenes. Some things, such as a few lyrics, the dream falling from the ceiling, the "what an interesting song" part where the guy is spinning on the bracket, etc., are not confined to the border. The thickness of the border, as well as its color, also changes throughout the video. Then when the video of you starts to play, it seems like you are referring to the border around you as a door, and these doors start doing some really interesting things and at some points there are many doors on screen, and even doors within doors. At 2:57 you can even see one of these doors forming around two other doors of you playing music. Then at 3:13, all of the scene with the set (really the whole video so far) goes through ANOTHER door (this time an actual door) and into your room, which has no borderdoor around it until the ceiling "goes." This seems super intentional but I'm not quite sure what the border/door signifies in the context of this songvideo. My initial theory is that the border represents a view into a dream, and that whatever escapes that dream view is somehow escaping the dreamscape. But, like I said, I'm not sure. Regardless, I love it and think it/you are amazing.
096520.answer: it represents "i'm in way over my head and i have no idea how to finish this video in my lifetime and make it actually the way i want it, so i'm fucked. and i just realized borders make most things look better, so that is somewhat of a liferaft for me in this situation" holy smokes you are very friendly

096810.question: It seems like your current project still has a long way to go before seeing the light of day. This makes me wonder how Money came together so quickly after the release of I'm A Princess, and why this song isn't working out as well. Care to shed some light on this?
096810.answer: it's actually working out too well. that's the problem the first 2 weeks of "money" i attempted to do the 2 week schedule. i had the time very carefully mapped out. it only allowed about 15 hours to do the instrumental recording. it just wasn't enough. But the writing was also rushed - i skipped the 'general writing' which means no other songs got written before jumping to select 'money'. And i also was limited to songs that had more content written, rather than picking a tiny fragment. so the options for a selection were limited. The biggest time gain on "money" was the decision to do the graphics drastically simpler. it was liberating. For this current one, the time has come to make a series of updates and developments in the music recording department which will help drastically streamline the entire process for decades to come

096903.question: Hi Bill, I recently wrote a full song (Chords, melody, lyrics, tempo, form) and I've started recording it. The problem is I'm really struggling with fleshing out the arrangement. So far I've recorded temp piano, guitar, and vocals.I feel like the song doesn't have any peaks and valleys, the verse chorus and bridge all feel at the same energy level. Maybe this is a writing or performance issue? I don't know what order to work on stuff e.g. should I have started with drums? I also don't know what sounds to use to fill out the arrangement? I'm just sitting in front of my computer scrambling to get anything that works, I spent all day yesterday working on it and all I achieved was one tiny counter melody part on vibraphone. I also don't know where these other parts should land and how to not make it sound too busy and cluttered. Any advice would be greatly appreciated! I love the arrangements on your songs because they are so detailed and intricate and I love th e variety of tones and timbres you use. Thanks!
096903.answer: i think i have the ultimate solution for this, because i think i've been through this exact same scenario before. and i can safely say that the only way i know how to solve this is to start with much much much shorter songs. Ultimately i feel like i didn't start making good progress on this until i actually started writing songs that were as short as 1 second. Then i started to watch all the necessary concepts and procedures take shape easily. and then you can gradually work your way up to longer songs after that. Starting with something full length is gonna be way too many huge unknown variables at the same time

096939.question: do you think that 7 day week cycles are the best option for the modern world? do follow traditional work/rest rhythms (work Monday - Friday, rest Saturday & Sunday)? if so, why? if not, what would be a better alternative?
096939.answer: i don't know, but, it's pretty good i like to use the 7 day cycle, but usually with a different starting point, and a different scheme for 'rest' and 'not rest' sometimes i've wished it could be 10 days, but it's much harder for it to feel valid, because the rest of the world is so hooked on to the 7 day. All our devices tell us where we are in the 7 day. And adhering to that has a validity that you just can't get with another value. However, i do think it's good to rotate it and have the start time be different, so that way i feel like it's my own, and is also not subject to random monday holidays

096989.question: A bit after the release of I'm A Princess, I realized the grammatical meaning of the 3rd verse (the one with the soldiers), and that, grammatically, "dreamed that it's ok" would refer to the soldiers doing the dreaming. I felt a bit disappointed when I realized this because to me it feels very strangely powerful to think of that line as disconnected from the previous lines in a songy sort of way, only being connected to the daydream line by a shared word, and perhaps referring to the narrator doing the dreaming. This interpretation also turns the previous lines from a sentence to just some relevant imagery, which also feels more powerful to me. Do you internalize that verse as one big sentence or as a series of disconnected lines? What did you intend?
096989.answer: i probably intended to find something better, but, i couldn't really figure out how to work the grammar to add up correctly and still get the sound i wanted. by the way, it's "i dreamed that it's ok" although the "i" is probably not vocalized. You can put the phrase boundaries in two different places. the soldiers "make sure i'm lonely through the daydream", ... or ... "through the daydream, i dreamed that it's ok". Hopefully by the end you've gotten a bit of both

097016.question: is there a reason that "memory" appears between aaaacv and frenca, then again between frenez and loveqa and yeat again between lovesz and zzzzya in the part of got some money where the 6-letter combinations are scrolling down the screen?
097016.answer: yes. What i would have preferred to do, is to be able to actually create that entire alphabetical phrase list. which i was able to generate quite easily, but the problem we run into, when the list goes into the graphics, .... the list is so long that it actually makes the computer lag, or probably even crash, depending on how you do it. There's literally millions of lines in that text pattern, if it were carried out properly from a to z across all 6 characters. So even though it's just text, it actually is an absurdly unnecessary strain on the memory of the scene, pretty much any way you slice it. And the truth is, in that scene, with the small amount of time it's shown, you'd never see all the lines. and also, another reason you don't wanna include the whole list is that the scroll direction would become incoherently out of phase. like those car wheels on tv that seem to move slow or backwards or whatever. So it turns out, even just to create the proper looking downward scroll, you need to reduce the number of elements drastically. like pretty much skip 99% of the parts during the fast scroll. But this still does create a continuity problem, because if anyone sees the (maybe 1) frame where you can see it jump from A to L or whatever, .... i feel there's gonna need to be an explanation there. So my explanation is 'memory' as a place holder for the perhaps millions of lines we've skipped

097163.question: What's a thing I can explore?

097164.question: I know you like to try and catch all your ideas. I used to too. At work in the amazon warehouse many ideas came to me. and I would run around like a crazy person trying to find a pen and paper to write them down. then at home after a while I ended up having a stack of these ideas. then two stacks and three. then I went for yoga teacher training and learned about aparigraha and wanted to become detached and the feeling I get when an idea comes feels very attached so I wanted to get rid of my stacks of ideas. so I got rid of most of them and kept a few. But now I'm thinking, why do I need to capture every idea? because I'm not the source of them. The source is endless! and if the source wanted me to have an idea at a certain point in time, it would send one, right? so maybe that's how I can remain detached while also being open to receiving ideas. But then again I have nothing to show for any of this yet, while you have much to show for your methods of capturi ng all possible ideas. So maybe I shouldn't have gotten rid of my stacks of ideas. Oh well. The past is the past.
097164.answer: you're right that there are infinite. but the reason i think you need to write them down is because they mostly probably will not come to you at your moment of deliberate songwriting. When you go to work on songwriting, on purpose, and you need ideas, ..... the ideas might not want to come, because they feel they are being watched. Ideas seem to come more readily when you are not expecting. that's why i think it's important to write these down, because this might be your main best source of ideas. Then, the songwriting department just has to learn how to work with ideas that are handed to them, from the list. then there's whole other department called the selecting department, but that's another story entirely

097275.question: Can you expand on this please: "if you can learn to understand the noise, then it will seem calm"? Like if you hear someone banging a wall, how would understanding that noise make it seem calm?
097275.answer: that's what we always do. Actually, our entire existence is making sense of immense noise. the cacophony of electrical signals hitting your brain, the sight and sound, your entire nervous system, .... you are being bombarded by information. it can take a human person at least a couple years just to figure out how to make sense of the basics. to walk, talk, identify objects, etc. But eventually, once you familiarize yourself with those things, they seem normal, and they become part of a normalized baseline state. You'll also notice that when people are sleeping with any type of noise or activity going on, they tend to be more likely to wake up when the noise changes. The more you understand what's making the sounds you're hearing, you can accept them into your reality fairly lovingly

097281.question: Hi Bill, I was watching one of your music videos (Slow Down), and you gave the public a look into your video creation process. I have tried replicating your steps, but I've had some trouble exploiting that computer glitch. Could you help me with this problem?
097281.answer: that part was fictional satire the bad news is i may be 1,000 steps ahead of your on video making BUT, the good news is, because i may be an idiot, i have a tendency to do about 900 too many steps. To take it back to the root of the problem, the first thing you wanna do if you are working on a computer is: find the Export. Find the feature of your computer that actually makes a video file, in 1 file, such as mp4, that you can play in a video player. Everything else is just working backwards from there, figuring out how to change what video it is. Expand the possibilities 1 step at a time. If your video file starts entirely black, the next thing i can suggest is try to make part of it white. If the whole thing is silent, the next step will be to try to make at least some of it non-silent. and take a picture of yourself doing it so you can remember how simplicity works, in case you find yourself in a complicated emergency later on down the road
