097285.question: i really wonder the deeper reasons and thinking behind you not wanting to make an album. you often answer that with "songs are stronger one at a time" which makes a lot of sense, and i guess i can grasp the idea of what you mean by that. however the experience of listening to n many amount of songs and an album which is n songs long feels really really different to me? and also, i see no reason behind why the songs included in the album should lose the power of them being experienced one at a time. if you craft it with ingenuity, which you always do at all of your crafts in my opinion as far as the works you have currently made go, they could still be considered as n separate songs if wanted to by the experiencer. however, give a much differently beautiful, not stronger by definition (let's hope that both experiences have the same amount of strength which is as strong as possible) ocean of feelings, with a longer ride i guess? being in control of the order o f recommended listening, being able to do lots of interesting twists and turns by simply i dont know putting in some interlude tracks or whatever _you_ are going to invent at that road, and therefore a longer greater narrative outside the singular ones could turn into something deeper emotionally, with more investment. the songs that can still be experienced as single pieces which are strong enough for them to be considered "good", could also have a double triple however many as you much meaning at the whole picture, and n many songs could still be themselves in their own way? one doesn't even need to publish them one at a time, simply just planning the whole process at the writing is enough to make it so, i guess, and they could come as singles, when finished also as a whole with the extra album touches if necessary. and as far as i understood you have no problems in the writing departmant which comes like a natural language to you. this would only differentiate the process of writ ing, the amount of production that will be needed to put in would not rise, since there are still n many of songs which is lesser than the amount that you are already going to make? maybe i'm a sucker for continuity and your work and just want to listen to an album that has been made from you, i don't know. but you also don't seem like being a person who willingly refuses having more meaning, especially when the work going to be done is not exponentially increasing, which it doesn't seem like at this case. am i missing something? i would love to hear your reasoning behind not wanting to make albums in more depth, but for me it feels like those pictures made from other pictures square by square, it doesn't have to be like a jigsaw puzzle, pieces don't need to feel empty at any time, but still, you can have n beautiful pictures and a bigger greater +1, as a bonus, with nothing to lose. thank you for all the inspiration and constant reminders of me having free will, it seems like i really do need that sometimes, and your work always finds a subtle way to ring that bell. sorry for the wall of text.
097285.answer: i always expected that to be true because a lot of people say it is, but it's not, for me. i really wanted it to be true so i've tried it many times with many different albums and it never seems true for me. the good news is i found out it is true for other things, things that are more than just songs it reminds me of how meals have their greatest effect when eaten 1 at a time if it's the longer ride, then the plea i would usually make is: 'please make it more than just songs.' A song's best friend is something that's not a song, and vice versa then please, please, (i would argue), make it more than just songs. i think this plays directly into the 'more' theme you are going for here, and i'm wondering why, in such a 'more' theme, you'd want to restrict it something so narrow as just a series of audio tracks i think so. i think you are putting me on the wrong side of the argument. i am arguing for something 'more' meaningful than an album, not less. in my opinion, at the length of an album, there's much stronger ways to use the same amount of time, in terms of creative audio/visual content. in my opinion for me personally, the downside to an album is the icky feeling it gives me when listening to it, and the inevitable fruitless search for 'which of these songs i like', (which bizarely always seems to be almost none). And yet, contrarily, any one of those songs can readily become a full blown anthem of life, when found/presented in a more specialized context: such as in a motion picture, or other significant life event

097337.question: the value i see in albums is that they are just another level of grouping, just as you could say a song is a grouping of sections, sections are groupings of phrases, phrases are groupings of melodic fragments, melodies are groupings of notes, etc. there's many different ways to analyze the groupings of a song. but anyway, an album is one way to be just one tier above songs in the grouping hierarchy. i tend to like albums that seem to form a coherent and meaningful group of songs, which for me tends not to be about what order they're in as much, unless there is a narrative element. but for me grouping things is always a way to generate new meaning; grouping anything at all creates an opportunity to see what the group means as a whole, and how different aspects of parts of the group contribute to that meaning. maybe you think this does not work particularly well with songs, but for me it sometimes does. i can relate to your experience of liking songs more when taken one at a time, but there are also important albums to me, that have a meaning in and of themselves as a whole, beyond just one or a small subset of 'good songs' in them. are there any albums like that for you?

097382.question: how do you decide whether to use uppercase or lowercase letters?
097382.answer: there are many ways, but here are some examples of where i would choose to use capital letters: If i'm starting a new sentence, and i need a little bit of extra conviction, i might use a capital letter to start. if i'm using chord symbols such as Bb. if i'm using acronyms, such as UNESCO. if i'm using the letter L and i feel that it won't be otherwise interpreted as L based on context. i might use them if i need emphasis or power, in the same way that the 'bold' style might be used, except capitals have the advantage of being available in places where bold is not. Or i might just use them for artistic embellishment. most other normal situations, i use lowercase, also known as the 'normal case'

097403.question: So, based on the music that exists, it is very clear that when lyrics and music work together to form a coherent whole, everything is amplified. Given this fact, it seems silly not to take advantage. But, the issue is, songs are supposed to be fun to listen to. At least I want my songs to be fun to listen to, that way people will want to listen to them while they work and such. But what if I want to write a song about something that is sad? Like, if I wanted to write a song about my dog dying (hypothetically), then the song would have to be slow and loud to match the terrible sadness of the death of my dog, right? But, would that song be fun to listen to? I wouldn't want to do the dishes while listening to a song that makes me feel like my dog died. So, my question is, how do I achieve a balance between lyrical and musical content while ensuring my music is enjoyable? Do I only write songs about things that are good? That seems awfully limiting. I look at th e songs that you make and the songs that other artists make about sad topics and those songs seem to sound happy while talking about things that are sad. Pink Floyd's Time, for example, talks about the stress of getting older and then it rips into a *sick* guitar solo. The thing is, it works really well, even though it doesn't really sound... sad? Like it sounds like how getting older feels, and even though getting older should feel sad, the solo doesn't feel sad, even though the solo sounds like how getting older feels. This appears to conflict with the transitive property. How do you do this?
097403.answer: i think you have received a good hint that writing sad songs with pleasant melodies is powerful. but really, to actually do this stuff (songwriting), it's so delicate that you never know when it's gonna work right. but the more you do it, the more likely it is that you will find yourself in a situation of writing something that really works for you. to open the floodgates a little, try to give yourself a challenge to write something that's not what you mean. songwriting thrives on reverse psychology sometimes. that's because the universe thrives on reverse psychology. why? it's free games, for you and your friends to solve, through tears of joy

097404.question: How did you learn to factorize big numbers (>1000) in your head? Could you teach me how to do it?
097404.answer: only 1 step at a time. first, i'll tell you how to figure out if a number is even (divisible by 2). if the last digit is even, then the whole number is even. If it's even, divide it by 2, and set the 2 aside as one of the factors for your final answer. to divide a number by 2, try to separate the digits into groups that form numbers you already know how to divide by 2. for example, if you have 1634, ... you can split that into 16 and 34 next to each other. you can safely half each of those, side by side, and keep them next to each other. This is assuming that you already happen to know what 16 divided by 2 is, and what 34 divided by 2 is. If you didn't, then i will go back a couple of steps and just tell you the simple fact that 16 divided by 2 is 8 and 34 divided by 2 is 17. hopefully you can remember that. So you can conclude that 1634 divided by 2 is 817. I got carried away and gave you more like 13 steps instead of 1. i'll try to give fewer steps next time, but i promise to give you all the steps i know, if you want to know them. i apologize if you already knew all of those steps. in case you were looking for something more advanced, i can tell you that 2001 is an awesome checker for both 23 and 29 at the same time

097469.question: Please give us the rest of the factorizing steps!
097469.answer: i can't give them all at once, because there's way too many. but let's pick a random number up to a million and i'll try to tell you the first 3 things i would do. The number we're working with today is 306124. The first thing is, notice it's even. How do we know this? because the last digit is even. so first we gotta cut the whole thing in half. this can be done by slicing it where you see even numbers that you can handle. so for me that's 30 6 12 4. cut those in half, and keep them in the same order, preserving the digits. so that makes 15 3 06 2.... or 153062. Next, notice it's still even. do the same thing again. this gets tricky because you have a lot of consecutive odd numbers in there. cutting numbers in half when they have a lot of odd digits, without paper, can be a little annoying. but if you can handle the 1530, then the 62 part is easy. 1500 in half is 750, plus the 15 is 765. and the 62. so 76531. Now it's odd and you can't divide it anymore. So you can go ahead and put some 2's in your final answer, because you divided it by 2, twice. so you know that your answer is going to include 2 twice. Now, you're left with an odd number: 76531. The next step is to check if it's divisible by 3. The trick for this is, and most people seem to know this trick, if the number is divisible by 3, all the digits are gonna add up to a multiple of 3. so you can group them. so, looking at 76531, .. knock out the 6, i can knock out 7 and 5 (75, mult of 3, or 57, either way, same thing) knock out the 3, ... and you're left with 1 which is non-3. so by knocking out digits and groups of digits which add to 3 or mult of 3, if all the digits got knocked out that way then we know it's a mult of 3, but if we were left with any non-3s, (which we were), then we know it's not a mult of 3. Ok, now the real game begins. We're going to check every other prime number, in ascending order. No need to check 5, because we can see that it's not a multiple of 5 (hopefully you can see that outright ... but the way to tell that is if the last digit is 0 or 5, which it's not). So next we're going to check 7. Every prime we're going to check from here on out will be based on the same system. We're going to manipulate the main number (76531) by adding or subtracting the checker as many times as we want. IF the main number is a mult of 7, then that means we can add or subtract 7 as many times as we want, and it should STILL be a mult of 7. We can ALSO DIVIDE the main number by ANYTHING and it should still be a mult of 7, if it originally was. So basically the idea is to do these manipulations in a way that gets you to something you recognize as a mult of 7 or not. There are many ways of doing this. First, if you want, you can just drop the 7 from the left. because this essentially would mean you're subtracting 70000. which, if the original number was a mult of 7, then it should still be a mult of 7 when you subtract 70000. so we'll knock out the 7, and you have 6531. Next, i'm going to do probably the most common technique, which is to work from the right. Here's an interesting principle: if we've already reduced the main number in the ways we've already reduced it (cut it in half until it's odd, divide by 3 until it's not a mult of 3, divide by 5 until it's not a mult of 5), then THAT MEANS that for ANY future prime number you wanna check, you can ALWAYS cause the number to level off with a zero at the end by either adding or subtracting THE CHECKER OR ITS TRIPLE. That's because all your future prime numbers that you're gonna check are gonna end in either 1,3,7, or 9. So that means those are always either 1 or 3 away from 10. And if you've already reduced your main number properly, then that number will ALSO always be either 1 or 3 away from the nearest 10. So you just pick which maneuver to make based on what you need. So looking at our main number as it stands now, 6531, and if we're checking for 7, i can tell you that what you wanna do is subtract 21. That's how you can get it to level off to a zero at the end. 6510. and of course you can drop the zero, because that does NOT change whether or not the main number is divisible by 7. so that leaves you with 651. the same move again works: subtract 21, gets you to 630 and drop the zero, you have 63. Do you recognize it yet, as something that you know to be a multiple of 7, or something you know to not be a multiple of 7? you might recognize 63 as a multiple of 7. But in case you don't see that, you could make another move, by adding 7, and you get 70, drop the zero, is 7. Now do you recognize it (7) as either being a multiple of 7 or non-multiple of 7? i think you do. So we can confirm that 7 is one of the factors. next comes the not so fun part where you have to actually divide 76531 by 7. then when you get the result, continue working with this new main number, and you also have to check 7 again on that number in case it's in there twice

I don't know what I'm seeking out. maybe I'm seeking out general adventure and meaning and purpose. or maybe I'm seeking out other people up to the same thing. maybe all of those things and then some. 098323.question: every time i hear a producer talk about their process, they always say that they can hear the finished song in their head, and they basically just copy what they hear onto the computer, but but whenever i try to produce a song, my head is empty. i just have zero idea what to do besides add the basics (like drums, bass, chords etc.) and i always end up with a song that is disappointing and then i spiral. do you have the same thing where you can hear the finished song in your head? how do i produce a song that doesnt sound like the most boring thing in the world?
098323.answer: i'm trying to tell from your description whether you write the song first ..... if you don't, i would suggest trying that. you can use paper or demo recordings to help you remember it, because brand new songs are hard to remember accurately. when i say 'writing' i mean only specifically enough for a person to play and sing it with 1 instrument. no need to plan out everything, just the melody/lyric/chords, an exact tempo, and a full roadmap. that's my method. That doesn't mean i know exactly how the song will sound before i produce it, and it doesn't stop me from feeling empty sometimes at the start of production, but, what's most important is that i do know exactly how the song goes. there's already enough unknowns in the production process details, even after knowing the song

098424.question: Hey Bill, I feel hopeless. I feel trapped by my parents, who have kept me locked up all my life. With quarantine, things just got worse and it honestly feels like I'll never find my way out of this place, out of their influence. I'm about to turn 18 and next year I should be heading to college. However, I can't go anywhere out of state because my parents say they won't pay for it, but they do have the money to do so, which means I can't apply for any financial aid. So I'm basically an adult now, but I can't begin to act like one because I have neither money nor a car or anything. I've just wanted to break free for as long as I can remember, and for the last few years I kept myself studying hard considering that'd provide for me, it would give me a way out. But now that the time has actually come for me to go to college, and I realize I don't have any passions anymore and the only thing that's left is a escape, which it won't provide either. Everyday I h ear more sarcastic comments about how everything I do is flawed and I'm never enough and I just don't want to keep doing this, taking everything they say to me. And I genuinely can't see this going on for more 5 years or so, till I finish college and get a job, without me completely falling apart. I just don't know how long I'll be able to hold on. I feel hopeless. Do you happen to have any kind words?
098424.answer: write an update to this in 5 days. i'm not sure if that will help, but i'd be curious to put the 2 reports side by side. could be a starting point

098448.answer: "do you remember the way that we dreamed we could change our lives" is not a very good line and i'm sorry about that. but, "do you feel like changing your mind" i feel is a strong line, for many reasons. it's a question, so that allows multiple answers. it is also about "changing your mind" which has multiple outcomes because there's multiple things you can change it to. also, the phrase "changing your mind" means multiple things. it is normally expected to mean changing your plan or opinion, but, it can also mean changing your method of thinking. a lot of possibilities. Also the word "mind" seems to be an escalation from the word "lives". "mind" is a nice escalation from "life", because the mind can actually imagine and change the course lives

098726.question: hihihihihi bill I got my first job ever, in a retail place, and I noticed something that I think is mind blowing. People come into the store in waves. As in, the store will be completely empty, then someone comes in, and within about five minutes, 2-3 other people or groups come in after them. Separate groups. From different entrances. Coming in within minutes of each other. CONSISTANTLY. Then they clear out around the same time too. Groups that are NOT TOGETHER. NOT COMMUNICATING. NOT TRAVELING TOGETHER. and yet they are. It's almost totally predictable (there are outliers). And i get that sometimes there are other factors, like the bus stopped here, or it's after the lunch rush and everyone is coming after eating, or there's construction outside bringing people this way, or things like that. But I am not aware of any of that happening. And it's like, are they coordinating, talking to each other on l ittle walkie talkies? No! They're just doing it naturally, some how. Is there some other reason that I'm missing? Or do we humans just have some kind of subconscious magnetism to each other??
098726.answer: it's a combination of reasons that are knowable (such as bus schedules, etc), reasons that are not knowable (too subtle), and then finally you can add at least a 300% hype bias, like finding shapes in the clouds. the shapes distract you from the non-shapes every time. and another bonus reason i just thought of, which is that if people see people go into a store, that makes it seem suddenly more appealing to go into that store

098783.question: How do you make your chords so interesting? You got like 6 and slash and suspended and add9s. How do you make them sound so good?
098783.answer: first, pay no attention to how good you think they look in a chord symbol, as you said, you wanna know about how they sound. now that i got that out of the way, it's pretty simple, here's how you do it: spend your life living and discovering songs, and finding the ones that you love the most, the ones that seem to improve your life, ... etc. Also, spend a lot of time just raw at the instrument (chordal instrument) trying to use the instrument to improve your life. i just realized what i'm trying to explain is exactly the same thing as learning a language. hear other people communicate things to you, try to communicate things to other people, and just keep doing that and after a couple of years you will be pretty good, after about 7 years you will be great, and after about 14 years you'll be... really great. and so on.

098816.question: Part of what makes your songs so good is that you sort of force people to actively listen by including relevant visual information. There are aspects of music that many don't even hear or notice unless being shown what it is and when to listen for it. In so many words, your videos are just as much a part of your songs as the music is. I'm sure you're well aware of this so my question is, how do you go about applying this? When you're recording the music, do you already have ideas for how to visualize it and do you initially write your songs in a way that you feel will translate well to video?
098816.answer: i have no idea. i've barely been able find a way, and even if i do, sometimes it takes about 1000 years. sometimes that makes it so discouraging that it takes me another 1000 years to recover yes, but that doesn't mean i'll be able to succeed in producing that, visually a new writing technique is to imagine visual scenes first, and then see what music seems to belong there. That has nothing to do with producing the video, the video might not even look like that, but it turns out to be a useful songwriting technique. it turns out, music and non-music are best friends with each other

099395.question: what should one do if they're seen as awkward? I'm often told that I come off as a rude and arrogant person even when I don't intend to because I'm blunt and also slightly clueless about social norms. I'm sick of people's expectations but people in general are not willing to help you unless you're conforming? it's so hard to find a balance between being yourself and being what others expect you to be. I used to seek a lot of validation from others before, but now I'm slightly more self-confident. However, a few people have asked me if I'm depressed or something and try to figure out what's "wrong" with me (and they try to be subtle about it), and I just get the general feeling that people don't like being in my presence because I'm too uncomfortable or stand-offish. Although I've learned not to mind it too much, I feel this is only going to alienate me further from others and prevent me from getting things done. idk I'm just venting here, sorry
099395.answer: i'd say take all the energy you just spent regarding what other people think of you, and put it toward being who you actually think you should be. after a few years of some genuine devotion, you'll probably turn out to be a superstar

099428.question: I want to make songs in the future but I dont know where to start, I don't even know all the keys in piano, it's hard to start something that I don't know where to start of. How can you come up of making songs?
099428.answer: i'm not sure. i discovered most of the music basics when i was a very small child. but doing 'songs' still required a lot of additional spiritual exploration (or at least i chose to require that of myself), but i had a lot of musical experience to back it up. i'm not sure what it would be like to approach it without having that musical experience, but, in some ways i suspect it might have been simpler and more adventurous, with less blockages maybe. i've had to do a lot of soul-searching at some points, to coax the adventures out. but if i had no musical experience i suspect that the adventures might have been ready to go, right on the surface. i think i've seen other people work this way

099457.question: have you ever tried writing a song in the locrian mode
099457.answer: what happens when you try to base a song in locrian: it almost immediately tends to shift into neighboring relative normal modes. for example, if you start writing something in C locrian, it's going to have a tendency to start sounding like Bb minor, or maybe even Db major, or perhaps Ab mixolydian, etc... I think you'll find it will be an uphill battle to continue to 'prove' that C is actually the root of it

099611.question: Do you have any tips in regards to exploring new crazy and wacky chords out there that sound good?
099611.answer: yes. here's the best trick i can think of: the more you think about the whole situation, the better the chords get. figure out the whole reason for the song's existence. if it's in a movie, think about the whole story. if the song is in a restaurant, think about the restaurant and the location of the restaurant and everything about it. if the song is on a train, think about where the train goes. if the song is in your real life, think about your real life. that's where you'll find where all the deepest chords seem to mean everything. However, if you focus on just the chords, you'll find, bizarrely, none of them seem to feel like anything

099638.question: i have a question (so weird right) i was wondering if you have any advice for my "problem". you see, im actually pretty happy with my life at the moment. not because i get above-average grades, lots of money, or have a super cool skill, cuz i dont really (i mean,i would say im pretty good at drawing, but i hang around a lot of art kids so its more common) i dont mind my life at the moment, i think i have the knowledge and skillset i need to get through life ok right now... except one thing. you see, i love music, always have. my favorite types of music right now are 80s and 90s rock, early 2010s edm party stuff, mid 2010s pop, and random, not as well known, sometimes dumb or meaningless songs/jingles i find on youtube(such as Elise ecklund, daniel thrasher, tom mcgovern, you, etc) music is such a huge part of me, im actually named after a song by The Cure (kinda) and i would love to write some music, but at the moment, i cant. i cant read sheet music, never even had piano lessons as a kid, not too interested in my schools music classes, ive tryed to learn guitar, but couldnt really be bothered to memorize anything, the only instrument im currently interested in (other than still maybe guitar) is drums, but im not even to sure about that. even if could play something, i cant come up with original melodies easily AT ALL, its incredibly hard for me. idk why this particular thing is so hard for me, or why im so bothered by it. i really want to learn something, but i can almost never find the motivation to do so, which is weird, because ive found motivation for other things, ive learned to rollerskate and knit, etc. im sure if i did, i could be patient and improve my skills, like with my drawing or singing, or the above skills, but i cant find the motivation. what should i do? where do i find motivation? why cant i let this one thing go? im sorry for the long, kinda personal question, but idk, thought i might ask, you seem to kn ow music pretty well, and youre pretty good at what you do. also, if you answer this, feel free to cut out useless bits of question, including the apology, and thanks
099638.answer: it sounds like you want to 'write music', but you don't want to 'write music'. i think the key here is figuring out the difference between the thing you want to do, and the thing you don't actually want to do. for some reason you're thinking of them as the same thing right now, but they must be different somehow, based on the fact that you know you want to do 1, but you don't seem to want to do the other. so the whole key here is to try to understand in more detail what each thing is, until you realize how they are different

099682.question: do you care about the fact that we now call artists "content creators"? i mean it isn't wrong but it kinda screws everything about art, no?
099682.answer: i doubt it. it's just a longer phrase, so you are going to lose that extra 1 second of time if you do end up using that phrase. it's also less specific, so the advantage is it possibly encompasses more than just artists. but if you specifically think you're talking about an artist, then you might want to say 'artist' in that case, for 2 reasons: a shorter phrase and in that case more accurate. in other cases, a different description might be more applicable. 'bookreviewer'...... 'chef'...... many different terms, with varying levels of specificity, and varying levels of accuracy too, which of course is the nature of language probably, as usual

099723.question: Hey bill! I'm, as a bassits, having trouble to learn how to make walking basslines. Got any tips to help stuff walk?
099723.answer: there's 2 things i can recommend, separately. first, just try to let yourself know, whenever you think you hear someone doing it really good. you'll feel yourself instinctively saying "oh yeah.... yes, this feels really good, i'm enjoying this". just make a brief mental note of when you are feeling this. just be aware of that feeling, what it felt like, and what it seemed to sound like. Then, besides that, just spend a lot of time playing along to recordings where walking should happen. try some things, .... and you may notice it may feel a little uncomfortable if what you're doing does not give you the same "oh yeah" feeling that you got before, but, if you keep playing along with those songs, eventually you're gonna find it. you'd have to. it's like a rat finding cheese in a maze

099724.question: it feels like there's a level of disconnect between the narrators in your songs and the real bill wurtz. have you ever written / thought about writing something that really smashes that disconnect and explores your actual personal thoughts and feelings from your own actual perspective? what are your thoughts on writing personally vs based on somewhat different characters that somewhat embody how you feel, and your approach to that kind of system?
099724.answer: my songs don't usually have narrators, but, the song writer is definitely me i will try to find some examples of parts of my songs that tell unequivocally true statements, from my point of view: from the song 'more than a dream': "every day seems so different" "i can't believe what i'm seeing, it's more than a dream, and it's more than anyone ever dreamed in history" "and on the best days you'll believe again that the best dreams can be real again" from the song 'money': "it's time for the show" from the song "here comes the sun" "here comes the sun, bringing you love and shining on everyone" "i hope you know that there's no stranger strange enough" which, paraphrased more clearly, would be something like "i hope you're aware that every person in this world is a real person, just like you, and everyone would truly love each other if we knew who we all really were" "ding ding ding dang ding ding, put it into words and then send it all over the world" from the song "it's the first day of school (and i think i might quit!)": "gonna learn some new lessons i won't forget gonna write them all down in the language of love and then teach them to everyone" from the song "at the airport terminal": "at the airport terminal the planes are landing" "traveling somewhere and it feels fantastic, rolling across the terminal floor" (with 'rolling' meaning walking, possibly with a wheeled suitcase) "everybody here is having an unusual day"...."in an unusual time zone".... "and i'm feeling fine in an unusual way" from the song "just did a bad thing": "how many times is the game going to change" "it's the best scheme i have, and that's bad [good] enough for me", which would refer to any time i've ever truly given my best effort from the song "the easter bunny told me that christmas isn't real (but santa claus is still jesus)": "everything feels so alive for the very first time" which means "[around the christmas/holidays/late-december time, sometimes] there is a deeply warm joyous and magical feeling that i can't quite describe except by using [these words, sung with this melody and these chords, like this] from the song 'slow down': "and i think i'm bobblin to a brighter day" from the song 'long long long journey': "it's a long long long journey that we've been on, and it's a long long long story that can be told" "we've come a long long way" "there's still a long way to go" from the song "when i get older": "when i get older, i'm gonna be stronger, so i can lift up the whole entire world" which more correctly translates to "sometime in the future i'd like to have the ability to deeply inspire many many many people, maybe so much that it might fulfill some of my unmet childhood needs somehow" "and i don't quite know what it means, but it feels like the song knows me" (this describes any experience of listening to a song that really hits strongly, perhaps beyond my ability to fully understand exactly why) from the song "i'm best friends with my own front door": "i saw the sign, i saw the sign, it's a bad bad sign" which refers to the fact that i realized that i only have 4 more hours to compose the entire remainder of this song, if i wanna have any chance of staying in line with my new extremely ambitious production goal of 1 song/video released every 2 weeks "cuz i'm hungry [to achieve my goals] and scared and i can't find the truth [figure out how the hell to do this, because i've been trying for so many years] so i'm leaving [so i don't give a fuck i'm gonna accomplish this NOW] oh, there's my balloon [holy crap i'm actually doing it, it's as if i've just been able to grab onto a balloon that can now carry me up and away from the pit of eternal failure i thought i was falling into]" "that's how the game begins, oh, that's how i get home again" [hopefully this is the beginning of a continued trend of achieving my production goals, which i've been seeking so deeply for so long, as one would seek their true home]" from the song "hallelujah": "hallelujah" (that's just a true word, it's always true when anyone says it) from the song 'hello sexy pants': "but down in congress, all the boys get mad" (actually writen like a fictional line, but it happens to be true that "the representatives on the floor of a 2-party government tend to argue with each other") "everywhere somebody lonely is still feeling blue" (i'm just assuming this must be statistically true) from the song 'and the day goes on': "and the day goes on" which more accurately means, "and time/life goes on" "hold on"..."stay strong"... which is just general encouragement i would give to anyone, as time and life goes on from the song "La de da de da de da de day oh": "i don't have enough time to say the things i wanna say [i feel like i'm not going to have enough time to write and produce all the material i want to express, which is mostly because of the high quantity of things that i want to express, combined with the high amount that i care about it which will cause me to take it so seriously that it will therefore probably take me a long time. at least this is currently how i'm feeling in februrary of 2009 as i say this]" "i wanna write a song"....."is that so wrong" [asking myself this, around february 2009, when i was feeling like i definitely hadn't written enough songs] "La de da de da de da de day oh" [simulation of what it might sound like, to sing such a song] "i went down to the mall, then they closed down the mall" [written with a fictional spirit, but it's almost completely based on that time i went to my local mall and i noticed that about 75% of the stores in the mall seemed to have suddenly gone out of business, and i didn't know why, and it felt spooky from the song "outside": "gonna go out and away from the lines" (just describing one of my typical creative goals) from the song "got to know what's going on": "give me a chance to believe it" (this is just a general prayer to be able to find genuine truths that can be believed in) "we've got to know what's going on" which means "it seems like we all really would like to know what's really going on in the world, and why, and what it all means... or at least i would certainly like to know" "we've got to know so we can be strong" which means "it feels like we'd all probably find a lot of strength in truly knowing and understanding the world" "whatever it is i'll believe it" (whatever the realest greatest deepest truth is, i promise to believe it) from the song "in california": "in california you can smoke marijuana [i'm pretty sure marijuana is now legal in california (for medical purposes at least) (at the time of writing, in 2011) and the reason this seems like interesting news is because marijuana has been illegal in most places for a very long time]" "in california you love who you want to [i'm pretty sure there's no gender restrictions on marriage, in california, (at the time of writing, in 2011) which is interesting because i think that's been illegal in most other states for a long time]" from "alphabet shuffle" "1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9, i'm alive" from various extremely short videos/songs: "i've been thinking a long time" "music makes me feel so interesting" "get ready for november" [on halloween which is the last day of october and thus right before the beginning of november] "i'm addicted to sunshine" "yes i like music" "just wanna make longer videos, ones that last a really really long time" "just wanna make stronger [LONGER! LONGER THAN 6.5 SECONDS PLEASE] videos, online" "time to rearrange my world" [time to try a new configuration of furniture in my bedroom/studio so that the desk faces away from the wall, toward the door, to hopefully give me a more professional attitude, as opposed to the previous configuration of facing the wall, as it always did before the time of saying this which is april 7, 2011] "hello, i'm a piece of garbage" which is a dramatization/paraphrase/summarization in 2015 of a 2007 journal entry i found which seemed to be completely devoid of any useful content and was also written during an extremely bad time in my life, at least according to my memory of it "oh hi, thanks for checking in, i'm still a piece of garbage" which is a dramatization/paraphrase/summarization in 2015 of another 2007 journal entry i found (it's from slightly later than the previous page i found and dramatized) which seemed to have the same exact sort of terrible and useless flavor as the note i had found just moments ago for the previous dramatization "are you the real you?" which is a 2015 paraphrase/dramatization of a 2004 journal page which actually said "how happy would you be if someone were 'examining' your life right now?.... how does your life hold up under the 'pressure of the pen'?" "i'm gonna figure out what everything means" which is a 2015 dramatization/paraphrase of the time in early 2011 when i spent several weeks trying to come up with some kind of actual scientific thesis about the exact effects that various chord sequences have on the perceived meaning of the songs they're used in "got to know (just) what i'm doing with my life" which is a 2015 dramatization/summary of what i was probably feeling when i started much more actively pursuing keyboardplaying+singing in july of 2008 it seems that one of the best ways to get real potent results is to use a lot of truth mixed with some creative alternatives to the truth. if done right, this almost has the effect of training the soul to spot the truth. the soul seems to be nourished by this. at least that's the way it feels for me

099878.question: Looking back at old questions, you seem pretty resolute in the idea that melody/lyrics come first, the melody has "chord residue" on it, and then you form the chords etc around that. That makes a lot of sense to me, but I've found that since I'm not a lyricist (yet), that I tend to prefer to build a song from the emotions that I'm feeling, and those emotions come out most clearly in the form of a series of chords (with certain phrasings) on the piano. Melodies fall out later, sometimes out of those chord phrasings. Do you think this difference in approach is just a matter of opinion? Could your stronger focus on lyrics be what creates that difference? Or do you believe that I'd actually have a more fulfilling time with songwriting if I work on making lyrics and/or melodies first?
099878.answer: there's many different ways to do it. yours is good. if you ever get restless, you can switch, but you don't have to i might be focusing on the lyrics slightly more than you might be, but i also focus on lyrics less than someone who writes lyrics first with no melody. i almost never do that. so in that sense i am somewhere in the middle. lyric/melody are linked for me, and that package is usually the driving force, but sometimes i do things differently. sometimes a vamp will be the first thing. sometimes a melody (no lyric) will be the first thing. occasionally lyric with no melody will be first, but that's only when i'm playing a ridiculous game i call "title first", and that's just for the title if you start to get bored doing it the way you are doing it, then you could try other ways. but if you are enjoying your way then that means it's going good

099914.question: A common criticism of my songs is that my mixes should be improved, but I have never really gotten any specific tips for a better mix. Do you have any tips for a generally good mix?
099914.answer: you have to start with what you can hear. if you like your mixes the way they are, then there's no change that you can or should make. you have to do it based on what you hear. for example, if the trumpet is way way too loud...... if that bugs you when you listen to it, ... then you can turn it down. but if it doesn't bother you then there is no need to change it. If you already like it the way it is, and then you start changing it, you'll probably just end up making it worse. .... getting back to the original question, if someone else is claiming your 'mix' is 'bad', but not telling anything specific about what they don't like, then you can just maybe raise 1 eyebrow at them, if possible
